langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div.head: The Miseries of inforstMariage.
div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Ilford, Wentloe, and Bartley.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: But Francke, Franke, now we are come to the house, what shall we make to be our business?

sp.speaker: Ilford.
sp.p: Tut, let us be Impudent enough, and good enough.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: We have no acquaintance here, but young Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How no acquaintance: Angels guard me from thy company. I tell thee Wentloe thou art not worthy to wear guilt Spurs, clean Linen, nor good Clothes.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why for Gods sake?

sp.speaker: Ilford.
sp.p: By this hand thou art not a man fit to Table at an Ordinary, keep Knights company to Bawdy houses, nor Beggar thy Taylor.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why then I am free from Cheaters, clear from the Pox, and escape Curses?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why dost thou think there is any Christians in the world?

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Aye and Jews too, Brokers, Puritans, and Sergeants.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Or dost thou mean to beg after Charity, that goes in a cold suit already, that thou talkest thou hast no acquaintance here. I tell thee Wentloe thou canst not live on this side of the world: feed well, drink Tobacco, and be honoured into the presence, but thou must be acquainted with all sorts of men, Aye and so far in too, till they desire to be more acquainted with thee.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: True, and then you shall be accompted a gallant of good credit.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But stay, here is a Scrape-trencher arrived: How now blue bottle, are you of the house?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I have heard of many black Iacks Sir, but never of a blue Bottle.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Well Sir, are you of the house?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: No Sir, I am twenty yards without, and the house stands without me.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Prithee tell us who owes this building.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: He that dwells in it Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Who dwells in it then.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: He that owes it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What is his name.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I was none of his God-father.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Does master Scarberow lie here,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I will give you a rime for that Sir,
Sick men may lie, and dead men in their Graves,
Few else do lie abed at noon, but Drunkards, Punks, and knaves.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What am I the better for thy answer?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: What am I the better for thy question?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why nothing.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Why then of nothing comes nothing.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: 'Sblood this is a philosophical fool.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Then I that am a fool by Art, am better than you that are fools by nature.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Gentlemen, welcome to Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And well encountered my little Villain of fifteen hundred a year, 'sfoot what makest thou here in this barren soil of the North, when thy honest friends miss thee at London?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Faith Gallants it is the Country where my Father lived, where first I saw the light, and where I am loved,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Loved, Aye as Courtiers love Usurers, and that is just as long as they lend them money. Now dare I lay.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: None of your Land good Knight, for that is laid to mortgage already?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I dare lay with any man that will take me up.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Who list to have a Lubberly load.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
Sirrah wag, this Rogue was son and heir to Antony Nowe, Now, and Blind Moon. And he must needs be a scurvy Musician, that hath two Fiddlers to his Fathers: but tell me in faith, art thou not, nay I know thou art called down into the country here, by some hoary Knight or other, whoknowing thee a young Gentleman of good parts, and a great living, hath desired thee to see some pitiful
piece of his Workmanship, a Daughter I mean, Is it not, so?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: About some such preferment I came down.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Preferment, a good word: And when do you commence into the Cuckolds order, the Preferment you speak of when shall we have Gloves: when, when?

sp.speaker: Scarb.
sp.l: Faith gallants
I have been guest here but since last night.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why, and that is time enough to make up a dozen marriages, as marriages are made up nowadays. For look you Sir: the father according to the fashion, being sure you have a good living, and without Encumbrance, comes to you thus: — takes you by the hand thus: — wipes his long beard thus: — or turns up his Muchacho thus: — Walks some turn or two thus: — to show his comely Gravity thus: — And having washed his foul mouth thus: — it last breaks out thus. —

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: O God: Let us hear more of this?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Master Scarborrow, you are a young Gentleman, I knew your father well, he was my worshipful good Neighbour, for our Demenses lay near together. Then Sir, — you and I must be of more near acquaintance. — At which, you must make an eruption thus: — O God (sweet Sir)

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: 'sfoot, the Knight would have made an excellent Zany, in an Italian Comedy.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then he goes forward thus: Sir, myself am Lord of some thousand a year, a Widower, (master Scarberrow) I have a couple of young Gentlewomen to my Daughters, a thousand a year will do well divided among them? Ha, wilt not Master Scarborrow, — At which you out of your education must reply thus. — The Portion will deserve them worthy husbands: on which Tinder he soonest takes fire and swears you are the Man his hopes shot at, and one of them shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: If I did not like her, should he swear to the devil, I would make him forsworn.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then putting you and the young Pugs to in a close room together.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: If he should lie with her there, is not the father partly the Bawd?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
Where the young puppet, having the Lesson before from
old Fox, give the son half a dozen warm kisses, which after her fathers oaths, takes such Impression in thee, thou straight callest by Iesu Mistress, I love you: — When she has the wit to ask, but Sir, will you marry me, and thou in thy Cox-sparrow-humour repliest, Aye (before God) as I am a Gentleman will I, which the Father over-hearing, leaps in, takes you at your word, swears he is glad to see this; nay he will have you contracted straight, and for a need makes the priest of himself.
sp.l: Thus in one hour, from a quiet life,
Thou art sworn in debt, and troubled with a wife.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: But can they Love one another so soon?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, it is no matter nowadays for love, it is well, and they can but make shift to lie together.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: But will your father do this too, if he know the gallant breaths himself at some two or three Bawdy houses in a morning.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O the sooner, for that and the Land together, tell the old lad, he will know the better how to deal with his Daughter?
sp.l: The Wise and Ancient Fathers know this Rule,
Should both wed Maids, the Child would be a Fool.
sp.p: Come Wag, if thou hast gone no further than into the Ordinary fashion, meet, see, and kiss, give over: Marry not a Wife to have a hundred plagues for one pleasure: let us to London, there is variety: and change of pasture makes fat Calves.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: But change of women bald Knaves, Sir Knight.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Wag and thou beest a Lover but three days, thou wilt be Heartless, Sleepless, witless, Mad, Wretched, Miserable, and indeed, a stark Fool. And by that, thou hast been married but three weeks, though thou shouldst wed a Cynthia rara avis, thou wouldst be a man monstrous: A Cuckold, a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: And why is a Cuckold monstrous, Knight?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why, because a man is made a Beast by being married? Take but example thyself from the Moon, as soon as she is delivered of her great belly, doth she not point at the world with a pair of horns, as who should say, married men, some of ye are Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I conster more Divinely of their sex,
Being Maids, methinks they are Angels: and being Wives,
They are Sovereigns: Cordials that preserve our Lives,
They are like our hands that feed us, this is clear,
They renew man, as spring renews the year.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: There is never a wanton Wench that hears thee, but thinks thee a Coxcomb for saying so: Marry none of them, if thou wilt have their true Characters, I will give it thee, — Women are the Purgatory of men's Purses, the Paradise of their bodies, and the Hell of their minds; Marry none of them. Women are in Churches Saints, abroad Angels, at home Devils.
Here are married men enough, know this: Marry none of them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Men that traduce by custom, show sharpe wit
Only in speaking Ill, and practise it:
Against the best of Creatures, divine women
Who are Gods Agents here, and the Heavenly eye
By which this Orb hath her Maturity;
Beauty in women, get the world with Child,
Without whom, she were barren, faint, and wild.
They are the stems on which do Angels grow,
From whence Virtue is styled, and Arts do flow.

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Harcop and his Daughter Clare.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Let them be what Flowers they will, if they were Roses, I will pluck none of them for pricking my fingers. But soft, here comes a voider for us: and I see, do what I can, as long as the world lasts, there will be Cuckolds in it. Do you hear Child, here is one come to blend you together: he has brought you a kneading-tub, if thou dost take her at his hands,
sp.l: Though thou hadst Argus eyes, be sure of this,
Women have sworn with more than one to kiss.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay no parting Gentlemen: Hem.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.l: 'sfoot does he make Punks of us, that he Hems already?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Gallants,
Know old Iohn Harcop keeps a Wine cellar,
Has Travelled, been at Court, known Fashions,
And unto all bears habit like yourselves,
The shapes of Gentlemen and men of sort.
I have a health to give them ere they part.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Health Knight, not as Drunkards give their healths I hope, to go together by the ears when they have done?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My healths are welcome: welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Are we welcome Knight, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Welcome i'faith Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Prithee tell me hast not thou been a Whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: In youth I swilled my fill at Venus cup,
Instead of full draughts now I am fain to sup.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Why then thou art a man fit for my company:
Dost thou hear that he is a good fellow of our stamp,
Make much of his father.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The Father, and the Gallants have left me here with a Gentlewoman, and if I know what to say to her I am a villain, heaven grant her life hath borrowed so much Impudence of her sex, but to speak to me first: for by this hand, I have not so much steel of Immodesty in my face, to Parley to a Wench without blushing. I will walk by her, in hope she can open her teeth. — Not a word? — Is it not strange a man should be in a woman's company all this while and not hear her tongue. — I will go further? — God of his goodness: not a Syllable. I think if I should take up her Clothes too, she would say nothing to me. — With what words trow does a man begin to woe. Gentlewoman pray you what is it oclock?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Troth Sir, carrying no watch about me but mine eyes, I answer you: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And if you cannot tell, Beauty I take the Adage for my reply: You are naught to keep sheep.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yet I am big enough to keep myself.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Prithee tell me: Are you not a Woman?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I know not that neither, till I am better acquainted with a man.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And how would you be acquainted with a man?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: To distinguish betwixt himself and myself.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Why I am a Man.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: That is more than I know Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: To approve I am no less: thus I kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And by that proof I am a man too, for I have kissed you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Prithee tell me can you love?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, three or four things: I Love my meat, choice of Suitors: Clothes in the Fashion: and like a right woman I love to have my will.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What think you of me for a Husband?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Let me first know, what you think of me for a wife?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Troth I think you are a proper Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do you but think so?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Nay I see you are a very perfect proper Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It is great pity then I should be alone without a proper man.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Your father says I shall marry you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And I say God forbid Sir: I am a great deal too young.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I love thee by my troth.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O pray you do not so, for then you stray from the steps of Gentility, the fashion among them is to marry first, and love after by leisure.

sp.speaker: Scarb.
sp.p: That I do love thee, here by heaven I swear, and call it as a witness to this kiss.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You will not enforce me I hope Sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Makes me this woman's husband, thou art my Clare,
Accept my heart, and prove as Chaste, as fair.

sp.speaker: Clare,
sp.p: O God, you are too hot in your gifts, should I accept them, we should have you plead nonage, some half a year hence: sue for reversement, and say the deed was done under age.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Prithee do not Jest?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: No (God is my record) I speak in earnest: and desire to know Whether ye mean to marry me, yea or no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: This hand thus takes thee as my loving wife,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: For better, for worse.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Aye, till death us depart love.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why then I thank you Sir, and now I am like to have that I long looked for: A Husband.
sp.l: How soon from our own tongues is the word said,
Captives our maiden-freedom to a head.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Clare your are now mine, and I must let you know,
What every wife doth to her husband owe,
To be a wife, is to be Dedicate
Not to a youthful course, wild, and unsteady,
But to the soul of virtue, obedience,
Studying to please, and never to offend.
Wives, have two eyes created, not like Birds
To roam about at pleasure, but for two sentinels,
To watch their husbands safety as their own,
Two hands, ones to feed him, the other herself:
Two feet, and one of them is their husbands,
They have two of everything, only of one,
Their Chastity, that should be his alone.
Their very thoughts they cannot term them one,
Maids being once made wives, can nothing call
Rightly their own; they are their husbands all:
If such a wife you can prepare to be,
Clare I am yours: and you are fit for me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: We being thus subdued, pray you know then,
As women owe a duty, so do men.
Men must be like the branch and bark to trees,
Which doth defend them from tempestuous rage,
Cloth them in Winter, tender them in age,
Or as Ewes love unto their Eanlings lives,
Such should be husbands custom to their wives.
If it appear to them they have strayed amiss,
They only must rebuke them with a kiss,
Or Clock them, as Hens Chickens, with kind call,
Cover them under their wing, and pardon all:
No jars must make two beds, no strife divide them,
Those betwixt whom a faith and troth is given,
Death only parts, since they are knit by heaven:
If such a husband you intend to be,
I am your Clare, and you are fit for me.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: By heaven.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Advise before you swear, let me remember you,
Men never give their faith, and promise marriage,
But heaven records their oath: If they prove true,
Heaven smiles for joy, if not it weeps for you,
Unless your heart, then with your words agree,
Yet let us part, and less us both be free.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: If ever man in swearing love, swore true,
My words are like to his: Here comes your father.

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Harcop, Ilford, Wentloe, Bartley, and Butler.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Now master Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Prepared to ask how you like that we have done,
your daughters made my wife, and I your son.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And both agreed so.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We are Sir,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then long may you live together, have store of sons.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: It is no matter who is the father.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But son here is a man of yours is come from London.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And brought you Letters Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What news from London Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The old news Sir, the Ordinaries are full, some Citizens are bankrupts, and many Gentlemen beggars.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Clare here is an unwelcome Pursuivant,
My Lord and Guardian writes to me with speed,
I must return to London.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And you being Ward to him son Scarborrow,
And know him great, it fits that you obey him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: It does it does, for by an ancient law,
We are born free heirs, but kept like slaves in awe,
Who are for London Gallants?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Switch and Spur we will bear you company.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Clare I must leave thee, with what unwillingness
Witness this dwelling kiss upon thy lip,
And though I must be absent from thine eye,
Be sure my heart doth in thy bosom lie,
Three years I am yet a ward, which time I will pass,
Making thy faith my constant Looking-glass,
Till when.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Till when you please, where ever you live or lie,
Your loves here worn, your presence in my eye.

div.stage: Enter Lord Faulconbridge, and sir William Scarborow.

sp.speaker: Hunsd.
sp.l: Sir William,
How old say you is your kinsman Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Will,
sp.l: Eighteen my Lord, next Pentecost.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Bethink you good Sir William,
I reckon thereabout myself, so by that account
There is full three Winters yet he must attend,
Under our awe, before he sue his Livery:
Is it not so?

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: Not a day less my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Sir William you are his Uncle, and I must speak
That am his Guardian, would I had a son
Might merit commendations even with him.
I will title you what he is, he is a youth,
A Noble branch, increasing blessed fruit.
Where Caterpillar vice dare not to touch,
He is himself with so much gravity,
Praise cannot praise him with Hyperbole:
He is one whom older look upon, as one a book,
Wherein are Printed Noble sentences
For them to rule their lives by. Indeed he is one
All Emulate his vertues, hate him none.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: His friends are proud, to hear this good of him.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: And yet Sir William being as he is,
Young, and unsettled, though of virtuous thoughts,
By Genuine disposition, yet our eyes
See daily presidents, hopeful Gentlemen,
Being trusted in the world with their own will,
Divert the good is looked from them to Ill,
Make their old names forgot, or not worth note
With company they keep, such Revelling
With Panders, Parasites, Prodigies of Knaves,
That they sell all, even their old fathers graves.
Which to prevent, we will match him to a wife,
Marriage Restrains the scope of single life.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: My Lord speaks like a father for my Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: And I have found him one of Noble parentage,
A Niece of mine, nay I have broke with her,
Know thus much of her mind, what for my pleasure
As also for the good appears in him,
She is pleased of all that is hers to make him King.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.p: Our name is blessed in such an honoured marriage

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Also I have appointed Doctor Baxter,
Chancellor of Oxford to attend me here
And see he is come. Good master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Bax.
sp.l: My honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: I have possessed you with this business master Doctor

sp.speaker: Baxt.
sp.p: To see the contract betwixt you honoured Niece and master Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: It is so, and I did look for him by this.

sp.speaker: Bax.
sp.p: I saw him leave his horse as I came up.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: So, so.
Then he will be here forthwith: you Master Baxter
Go Usher hither straight young Katherine,
Sir William, here and I will keep this room till you return.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: My honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: It is well done Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Kind Uncle.

sp.speaker: willi.
sp.l: Thanks my good Cuz.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: You have been welcome in your Country Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: The time that I spent there my Lord was merry.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: It was well, it was very well, and in your absence,
your Uncle here and I, have been bethinking
what gift betwixt us we might bestow on you,
That to your house large dignity might bring,
With fair increase, as from a Crystal spring.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: My name is bound to your beneficence,
your hands hath been to me like bounties purse,
Never shut up, yourself my foster-Nurse:
Nothing can from your honour come; prove me so rude,
But I will accept to shun Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: We accept thy promise, now return thee this,
A virtuous wife, accept her with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: My honourable Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Fear not to take her man, she will fear neither,
Do what thou canst being both abed together.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O but my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: But me a Dog of wax, come kiss, and agree,
Your friends have thought it fit, and it must be.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I have no hands to take her to my wife.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How Sauce-box.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O pardon me my Lord the unripeness of my years,
Too green for government, is old in fears
To undertake that charge.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Sir, sir, I and sir knave, then here is a mellowed experience knows how to teach you,

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O God.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: O Iacke.
How both our cares, your Uncle and myself,
Sought, studied, found out, and for your good,
A maid, a Niece of mine, both fair and chaste,
And must we stand at your discretion.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O Good my Lord
Had I two souls, then might I have two wives,
Had I two faiths, then had I one for her,
Having of both but one, that one is given
To Sir Iohn Harcops daughter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Ha, ha, what is that, let me hear that again?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: To Sir Iohn Harcops Clare I have made an oath,
Part me in twain, yet she is one half of both.
This hand the which I wear it is half hers,
Such power hath faith and troth betwixt couples young,
Death only cuts that knot tide with the tongue.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: And have you knit that knot Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I have done so much, that if I wed not her,
My marriage makes me an Adulterer,
In which black sheets, I wallow all my life,
My babes being Bastards, and a whore my wife.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Ha, is it even so, My secretary there,
Write me a Letter straight to Sir Iohn Harcop,
I will see Sir Iacke and if that Harcop dare,
Being my Ward, contract you to his daughter.
My steward too, post you to Yorkeshire,
Where lies my youngsters Land, and sirrah,
Fell me his wood, make havoc, spoil and waste.
Sir you shall know that you are Ward to me,
I will make you poor enough: then mend yourself.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.l: O Cozen.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: O Uncle.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Contract yourself and where you list,
I will make you know me Sir to be your guard.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: World now thou seest what it is to be a ward.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: And where I meant myself to have disbursed
Four thousand pound, upon this marriage
Surrendered up your land to your own use,
And compassed other portions to your hands,
Sir I will now yoke you still.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: A yoke indeed.

sp.speaker: Huns.
sp.l: And spite of they dare contradict my will,
I will make thee marry to my Chambermaid. Come cuz.

sp.speaker: Bax.
sp.l: Faith Sir it fits you to be more advised.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Do not you flatter for preferment sir

sp.speaker: willi.
sp.l: O but good Cuz.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: O but good uncle could I command my love,
Or cancel oaths out of heavens brazen book,
Engrossed by Gods own finger, then you might speak.
Had men that law to love as most have tongues
To love a thousand women with, then you might speak.
Were love like dust lawful for every Wind,
To bear from place to place, were oaths but puffs,
Men might forswear themselves, but I do know,
The sin being past with us, the acts forgot,
The poor soul groans, and she forgets it not.

sp.speaker: willi.
sp.l: Yet hear your own case?

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: O it is too miserable:
That I a Gentleman should be thus torn
From mine own right, and forest to be forsworn.

sp.speaker: will.
sp.l: Yet being as it is, it must be your care,
To salve it with advice, not with despair,
you are his ward, being so, the Law intends,
He is to have your duty, and in his rule
Is both your marriage, and your heritage,
If you rebel against these Injunctions,
The penalty takes hold on you, which for himself,
He straight thus prosecutes, he wastes your land,
Weds you where he thinks fit, but if yourself
Have of some violent humour matched yourself,
Without his knowledge, then hath he power
To Merce your purse, and in a sum so great,
That shall for ever keep your fortunes weak,
Where otherwise if you be ruled by him
Your house is raised by matching to his kin.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Now death of me, shall I be crossed by such a Iacke, he wed
himself, and where he list: Sirrah Malapart, I will hamper you,
You that will have your will, come get you in:
I will make thee shape thy thoughts to marry her,
Or wish thy birth had been thy murtherer.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Fare pity me, because I am enforced,
For I have heard those matches have cost blood,
Where love is once begun and then withstood,

div.stage: Enter Ilford and a Page with him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Boy, hast thou delivered my Letter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Aye Sir, I saw him open the lips on it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He had not a new suit on, had he?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am not so well acquainted with his Wardrobe Sir, but I saw a lean fellow, with sunk eyes, and shamble legs, sigh pitifully at his chamber door, and entreat his man to put his master in mind of him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, that was his Taylor, I see now he will be blessed he profits by my counsel, he will pay no debts before he be arrested, nor then neither, if he can find ever a beast that dare but be bail for him, but he will seal in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir, he will imprint for you as deep as he can.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good, good, now have I a Parsons Nose, and smell tithe coming in then. Now let me number how many rooks I have half undone already this Term by the first return: four by Dice, six by being bound with me, and ten by queens, of which some be Courtiers, some Country Gentlemen, and some Citizens Sons. Thou art a good Franke, if thou purgest thus, thou art still a Companion for Gallants, mayst keep a Caramite, take Physic, at the Spring and the fall.

sp.speaker: wont.
sp.p: Franke, news that will make thee fat Frank.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Prithee rather give me somewhat will keep me lean,
I have no mind yet to take Physic.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Master Scarberrow is a married man.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then heaven grant he may, as few married men do, make much of his wife.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why? wouldst have him love her, let her command all, and make her his master?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: No no, they that do so, make not much of their wives, but give them their will, and it is the marring of them.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Honest Franke, valorous Francke, a portion of thy wit, but to help us in this enterprise, and we may walk London street and cry pish at the Sergeants.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You may shift out one term, and yet die in the Counter, these are the scabs now that hang upon honest Iob, I am Iob, and these art the scurvy scabs, but what is this your pot seethes over withal?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Master Scarborrow is a married man.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: He has all his land in his own hand.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: His brothers and sisters portions.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Besides four thousand pound in ready money with his wife.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A good talent by my faith, it might help many Gentlemen to pay their Tailors, and I might be one of them.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Nay, honest Frank, hast thou found a trick for him, if thou hast not, look here is a line to direct thee. First draw him into bands for money, then to dice for it: Then take up stuff at the Mercers, straight to a punk with it: Then mortgage his Land, and be drunk with that: so with them and the rest, from an Ancient Gentleman, make him a young beggar.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What a Rogue is this, to read a lecture to me, and mine own lesson too, which he knows I have made perfect to nine hundred fourscore and nineteen. A cheating Rascal will teach me that have made them that have worn a spacious Park, Lodge and all of their backs this morning: been fain to pawn it afore night, and they that have stalked like a huge Elephant, with a Castle on their necks, and removed it to their own shoulders in one day which their fathers built up in seven year, been glad by my means, in so much time as a child sucks, to drink bottle Ale, though a punk pay for it. And shall this Parrot instruct me?

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Nay but Franke.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
A rogue that hath fed upon me, and the fruit of my wit like Pullen from a Pantlers chippings, and now I put him into good cloths to shift two suits in a day, that could scare shift a patched shirt once
in a year, and says prayers when he had it: hark, how he prates.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Besides Franke, since his marriage, he stalkes me like a cashiered Captain discontent, in which Melancholy, the least drop of mirth, of which thou hast an Ocean, will make him, and all his ours for ever.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Says mine own Rogue so, give me thy hand then, we will do it, and there is earnest.
'sfoot you Chitrtiface, that looks worse than a Collier thorough a wooden window, an Ape afeared of a whip, or a Knaves head, shook seven years in the weather upon London-bridge. Do you Catechise me?

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Nay but valorous Franke, he that knows the secrets of all hearts, knows I did it in kindness.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Know your seasons: besides, I am not of that Species for you to instruct. Then know your seasons.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: 'sfoot friends, friends, all friends: Here comes young Scarborrow, should he knew of this, all our designs were prevented.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What, melancholy my young master, my young married man, God give your worship joy.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Joy, of what Franke?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Of thy wealth, for I hear of few that have joy of heir wives

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: who weds as I have to enforced sheets,
His care increaseth, but his comfort fleets.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Thou having so much wit, what a Devil meantest thou to marry?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O speak not of it,
Marriage sounds in mine care like a Bell,
Not rung for pleasure, but a doleful knell.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A common course, those men that are married in the Morning, to wish themselves buried ere night.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I cannot love her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: No news neither, wives know that is a general fault amongst their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I will not lie with her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
Scar.
sp.p: Why did she marry me, knowing I did not love her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: As other women do, either to be maintained by you, or to make you a Cuckold. Now sir, what come you for?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: As men do in haste, to make an end of their business.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Whats your business?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: My business is this Sir, this Sir, and this Sir,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The meaning of all this Sir.

By this is as much as to say Sir, may Master. has sent unto you. By this is as much as to say Sir, my master has him humbly commended unto you, and by this is as much as to say, my master craves your answer.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Give me your Letter. And you shall have this Sir, this Sir, and this Sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilford.
sp.p: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Because as the learned have very well instructed me, Qui supranos, nihil ad nos, and though many Gentlemen will have to do with other men's business, yet from me know, the most part of them prove knaves for their labour.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: You have the Knave i'faith Franke.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Long may he live to enjoy it. From Sir Iohn Harcop of Harcop, in the County of Yorke Knight, by me his man, to yourself my young master, by these presents greeting.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How camest thou by these good words?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: As you by your good clothes, took them upon trust, and swore I would never pay for them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Thy master Sir Iohn Harcop writes to me,
That I should entertain thee for my man,
His wish is acceptable, thou art welcome fellow.
O but thy masters Daughter, sends an Article
Which makes me think upon my present sin,
Here she remembers me to keep in mind
My promised faith to her, which I have broke.
Here she remembers me I am a man,
Black tore with perjury, whose sinful breast,
Is Charactered like those cursed of the blessed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How now my young Bully, like a young wench forty weeks after the loss of her Maidenhead, crying out.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Trouble me not,
Give me Pen, Ink, and Paper, I will write to her,
O? but what shall I write?
Mine own excuse, why no excuse can serve
For him that swears, and from his oath doth swerve?
Or shall I say, my marriage was enforced,
It was bad in them, not well in me to yield.
Wretched thee to whose marriage was compelled,
I will only write that which my grave hath bred,
Forgive me Clare, for I am married:
It is soon set down, but not so soon forgot, or worn from hence.
Deliver it unto her, there is for thy pains,
Would I as soon could cleanse these perjured stains.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Well, I could alter mine eyes from filthy mud into fair water: you have paid for my tears, and mine eyes shall prove bankrupts, and break out for you, let no man persuade me, I will cry, and every Town betwixt Shoreditch-church and Yorke bridge, shall bear me witness.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I will take my leave of you,
She that I am married to but not my wife,
Will London leave, in Yorkeshire lead our life.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: We must not leave you so my young Gallant,
We three are sick in state, and your wealth must help to make us whole again.
For this saying, is as true as old:
Strife nursed betwixt man and wife, makes such a flaw,
How great soever is their wealth, it will have a thaw,

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Harcop with his Daughter Clare, and two younger Brothers, Thomas, and Iohn Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Brothers to him ere long shall be my son,
By wedding this young girl: You are welcome both,
Nay kiss her, kiss, though that she shall
Be your Brothers wife, to kiss the cheek is free.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Kiss, 'sfoot what else? thou art a good plump wench, I like you well, prithee make haste and bring store of boys, but be sure they have good faces, that they may call me uncle.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Glad of so fair a sister, I salute you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Good, good i'faith, this kissings good i'faith,
I loved to smack it too when I was young,
But Mum: they have felt thy cheek Clare, let them hear thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Such welcome as befits my Scarborrows brothers,
From me his troth-plight wife be sure to have,
And though my tongue prove scant in any part,
The bounds be sure are large, full in my heart.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Tut, that is not that we doat on wench, but do you hear Sir Iohn, what do you think drew me from London, and the Inns of Court, thus far into Yorkshire?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I guess to see this girl, shall be your sister.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Faith, and I guess partly so too, but the main was, and I will not lie to you, that your coming now in this wise into our kindred, I might be acquainted with you aforehand, that after my brother had married your daughter, I his brother might borrow some money of you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What? Do you borrow of your kindred Sir?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: 'sfoot what else, they having interest in my blood, why should not I have interest in their coin. Besides Sir, I being a younger brother, would be ashamed of my generation if I would not borrow of any man that would lend, especially of my affinity, of whom I keep a Calendar. And look you Sir, thus I go over them. First over my Uncles, often over mine Aunts, then up to my Nephews, straight down to my Nieces, to this Cousin Thomas, and that Cousin Ieffrey, leaving the courteous claw given to none of their elbows, even unto the third and fourth remove of any that hath interest in our blood. All which do upon their summons made by me, duly and faithfully provide for appearance, and so as they are, I hope we shall be, more endeared, entirely, better, and more feelingly acquainted.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: you are a merry Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: It is the hope of money makes me so, and I know none but fools use to be sad with it.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: From Oxford am I drawn, from serious studies
Expecting that my brother still had sojourned
With you his best of choice, and this good Knight.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: His absence shall not make our hearts less merry
Than if we had his presence. A day ere long,
Will bring him back, when one the other meets,
At noon at the Church, at night between the sheets.
We will wash this chat with wine. Some wine: fill up,
The sharpener of the wit, is a full cup.
And so to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Do, and I will drink, to my new sister, but upon this condition, that she may have quiet days, little rest a nights, have pleasant afternoons, be pliant to my brother, and lend me money when soever I will borrow it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay, nay, nay,
Women are weak and we must bear with them,
Your frolic healths, are only fit for men,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well, I am contented, women must to the wall, though it be to a feather-bed. Fill up then.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: From London am I come, though not with pipe and Drum,
Yet I bring matter, in this poor paper,
Will make my young mistress, delighting in kisses,
Do as all Maidens will, hearing of such an ill,
As to have lost, the thing they wished most,
A Husband, a Husband, a pretty sweet Husband,
Cry O, O, O, and alas, And at last ho, ho, ho, as I do.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Returned so soon from London? What is the news?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: O mistress, if ever you have seen Demoniceacleare look into mine eyes, mine eyes are Seuerne, plaine Seuerne, the Thamee, nor the River of Tweed are nothing to them: Nay all the rain that fell at Noah's flood, had not the discretion that my eyes have: that drunk but up the whole world, and I have drowned all the way betwixt this and London.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Thy news good Robbin.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: My news mistress, I will tell you strange news, the dust upon London way, being so great, that not a Lord, Gentleman, Knight, or Knave could travel, lest his eyes should be blown out: At last, they all agreed to hire me to go before them, when I looking but upon this Letter, did with this water, this very water, lay the dust, as well as if it had rained from the beginning of April to the last of May.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A Letter from my Scarborrow, give it thy mistress.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: But Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Prithee be gone,
I would not have my father nor this Gentlemen,
Be witness of the comfort it doth bring.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O but mistress.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Prithee begone,
With this, and the glad news, leave me alone.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: It is your turn Knight, take your liquor, know I am bountiful, I will forgive any man anything that he owes me, but his drink, and that I will be paid for.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: May Gentlemen the honesty of mirth
Consists not in Carousing with excess,
My father hath more welcomes than in wine:
Pray you no more.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Says my sister so, I will be ruled by thee then. Do you hear, in hope hereafter you will lend me some money, now we are half drunk let us go to dinner. Come Knight.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I am glad you are gone,
Shall I now open it: no, I will kiss it first,
Because his outside last did kiss his hand.
Within this fold, I will call it a sacred sheet,
Are writ black lines, when our white hearts shall meet,
Before I ope this door of my delight,
Methinks I guess how kindly he doth write,
Of his true Love to me, as Chuck, Sweetheart,
I prithee do not think the time too long,
That keeps us from the sweets of marriage rites,
And then he sets my name and kisses it,
Wishing my lips his sheet to write upon,
With like desire methinks as mine own thoughts,
Ask him now here for me to look upon,
Yet at the last thinking his love too slack,
Ere it arrive at my desired eyes,
He hastens up his message with like speed,
Even as I break this ope, wishing to read:
O: what is here? Mine eyes are not mine own? sure they are not,
Though you have been my lamps this sixteen years,
You do belie, my Scarborrow reading so;
Forgive him, he is married, that were Ill:
What lying lights are these. Look I have no such Letter,
No wedded syllable of the least wrong
Done to a Troth-plight-Virgin like myself.
Beshrew you for your blindness: Forgive him, he is married.
I know my Scarborrowes constancy to me,
Is as firm knit, as faith to Charity,
That I shall kiss him often, hug him thus,
Be made a happy and a fruitful Mother
Of many prosperous children like to him,
And read I, he was married? Asked forgiveness?
What a blind Fool was I? yet here is a Letter
To whom directed trow? To my beloved Clare.
Why Law?
Women will read, and read not that they saw,
It was but my fervent love misled mine eyes,
I will once again to the Inside, Forgive me, I am married:
william Scarborrow. He has set his name to it too,
O perjury? within the hearts of men
Thy feasts are kept, their tongues proclaimeth them.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sister, Gods precious, the cloths laid, the meat cools, we all stay, and your father calls for you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Kind Sir, excuse me I pray you a little,
I will but peruse this Letter and come straight.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Pray you make haste, the meat stays for us, and our stomachs
Ready for the meat, for believe this,
Drink makes men hungry, or it makes them lie,
And he that is drunk over night, in the morning is dry,
Seen and approved.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: He was contracted mine, yet he unjust
Hath married to another: what is my estate then?
A wretched maid, not fit for any man,
For being united his with plighted faiths,
whoever sues to me commits a sin,
Besiedgeth me, and who shall marry me:
Is like myself, lives in Adultery, (O God)
That such hard Fortune, should betide my youth.
I am Young, Fair, Rich, Honest, Virtuous,
yet for all this, whoever shall marry me
I am but his whore, live in Adultery.
I cannot step into the path of pleasure
For which I was created, born unto,
Let me live never so honest, rich or poor,
If I once wed, yet I must live a whore.
I must be made a strumpet against my will,
A name I have abhorred, a shameful Ill
I have eschewed, and now cannot withstand it
In myself. I am my fathers only child,
In me he hath a hope, though not his name
Can be increased, yet by my Issue
His land shall be possessed, his age delighted.
And though that I should vow a single life
To keep my soul unspotted, yet will he
Enforce me to a marriage:
So that my grief doth of that weight consist,
It helps me not to yield, nor to resist:
And was I then created for a Whore? A whore,
Bad name, bad act, Bad man makes me a scorn:
Then live a Strumpet? Better be unborn.
Sister, Pray you will you come,
Your father and the whole meeting stays for you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I come, I come, I pray return: I come.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I must not go without you.

sp.speaker: Clare,
sp.l: Be thou my Usher, sooth I will follow you
He writes here to forgive him, he is married:
False Gentleman: I do forgive thee with my heart,
Yet will I send an answer to thy letter,
And in so short words thou shalt weep to read them,
And here is my agent ready: Forgive me, I am dead.
It is writ, and I will act it: Be judge you Maids
Have trusted the false promises of men.
Be judge you wives, the which have been enforced
From the white sheets you loved, to them ye loathed:
Whether this Axiom may not be assured,

l.hi: Better one sin, than many be endured.

sp.l: My arms embracings, Kisses, Chastity,
Were his possessions: and whilst I live
He doth but steal those pleasures he enjoys,
Is an Adulterer in his married arms,
And never goes to his defiled bed,
But God writes sin upon the Teasters head.
I will be a Wife now, help to save his soul
Though I have lost his body, give a slake
To his iniquities, and with one sin
Done by this hand, end many done by him.
Farewell the world, then farewell the wedded joys
Till this I have hoped for, from that Gentleman,
Scarborrow, forgive me: thus thou hast lost thy wife,
Yet record would, though by an act too foul,
A wife thus did to cleanse her husbands soul.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Gods precious, for his mercy, where is this wench?
Must all my friends and guests attend on you?
Where are you Minion?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Scarborrow come close mine eyes, for I am dead.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: That sad voice was not hers I hope:
Who is this, my daughter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Your daughter,
That begs of you to see her buried,
Prays Scarborrow to forgive her: she is dead.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Patience good tears, and let my words have way
Clare, my daughter, help my servants there:
Lift up thine eyes, and look upon thy father,
They were not born to lose their light so soon,
I did beget thee for my comforter,
And not to be the Author of my care.
Why speakest thou not? Some help my Servants there:
What hand hath made thee pale? Or if thine own,
What cause hadst thou that wert thy fathers Joy,
The Treasure of his age, the Cradle of his sleep,
His all in all? I prithee speak to me?
Thou art not ripe for death, come back again,
Clare, my Clare, If death must needs have one,
I am the fittest, prithee let me go,
Thou dying whilst I live, I am dead with woe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What means this outcry?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O ruthful spectacle.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thou wert not wont to be so sullen child,
But kind and loving to thy aged father:
Awake, awake, If it be thy lasting sleep,
Would I had not sense for grief, nor eyes to weep.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What Papers this, the sad contents doth tell me,
My Brother writ, he hath broke his faith to her,
And she replies, for him she hath killed herself.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Was that the cause that thou hast soiled thyself,
With these red spots, these blemishers of beauty?
My child, my child, wast perjury in him,
Made thee so fair, act now so foul a sin,
That he deceived thee in a Mothers hopes,
Posterity, the bliss of marriage?
Thou hast no tongue to answer no, or Aye,
But in red Letters writes: For him I die.
Curse on his Traitorous tongue, his youth, his blood,
His pleasures, Children, and possessions,
Be all his days like winter, comfortless:
Restless his nights, his wants Remorseless,
And may his Corps be the Physicians stage,
Which played upon, stands not to honoured Age,
Or with diseases may he lie and pine,
Till grief wastes blood, his eyes, as grief doth mine.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: O good old man, made wretched by this deed,
The more thy age, were to be pitied.

div.stage: Enter Scarborrow, his wife Katherine, Ilford, Wentlo, Barley and Butler.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What ride by the gate, and not call, that were a shame i'faith.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: We will but taste of his Beer, kiss his Daughter, and to horse again, where is the good Knight hear?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You bring me to my shame unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Shamed of what, for deceiving of a wench, I have not blushed,
that have done it to a hundred of them.
In women's love he is wise, doth follow this,
Love one so long till her another kiss.
Where is the good Knight here?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O Brother, you are come to make your eye
Sad mourner at a fatal Tragedy.
Peruse this Letter first, and then this Corps.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O wronged Clare? Accursed Scarborrow?
I writ to her, that I was married,
She writes to me, forgive her she is dead:
I will balm thy body with my faithful tears,
And be perpetual mourner at thy Tomb,
I will sacrifice this Commit into sighs,
Make a consumption of this pile of man,
And all the benefits my parents gave,
Shall turn distempered to appease the wrath
For this blood shed, and I am guilty of.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Dear husband.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: False woman, not my wife, though married to me,
Look what thy friends, and thou art guilty of,
The murther of a creature, equalled heaven
In her Creation, whose thoughts like fire,
Never looked base, but ever did aspire
To blessed benefits, till you and yours undid her,
Eye her, view, though dead, yet she does look,
Like a fresh frame, or a new printed book
Of the best paper, never looked into,
But with one sullied finger, which did spot her,
Which was her own too, but who was cause of it,
Thou and thy friends, and I will loath thee for it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: They do belie her that do say she is dead,
She is but strayed to some by-gallery,
And I must have her again. Clare, where art thou Clare?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Here, laid to take her everlasting sleep.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: He lies that says so,
Yet now I know thee, I do lie that say it,
For if she be a villain like thyself,
A perjured Traitor, recreant, miscreant,
Dog, a dog, a dog, has done it.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O Sir Iohn Harcop.

sp.speaker: Hra.
sp.l: O Sir Iohn villain, to be troth thyself
To this good creature, harmless, harmless child,
This kernel hope, and comfort of my house,
Without Enforcement, of thine own accord,
Draw all her soul in the compass of an oath,
Take that oath from her, make her for none but thee,
And then betray her?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Shame on them were the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: But hark what thou hast got by it,
Thy wife is but a strumpet, thy children Bastards,
Thyself a murderer, thy wife, accessory,
Thy bed a stews, thy house a Brothel.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O, it is too true.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Aye, made a wretched father childless.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Aye, made a married man, yet wifeless.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thou the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Thou the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Curse on the day that ever it was begun,
For I an old man am, undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: For Charity have care upon your father,
Lest that his grief, bring on a more mishap,
This to my arms, my sorrow shall bequeath,
Though I have lost her, to thy grave I will bring,
Thou wert my wife, and I will thy Requiem sing:
Go you to the Country, I will to London back,
All riot now, since that my soul is so black.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Thus am I left like Sea-tossed-Mariners,
My Fortunes being no more than my distress,
Upon what shore soever I am driven,
Be it good or bad, I must account it heaven,
Though married, I am reputed not a wife,
Neglected of my Husband, scorned, despised,
And though my love and true obedience
Lies prostrate to his beck, his heedless eye,
Receives my services unworthily.
I know no cause, nor will be cause of none,
But hope for better days when bad be gone,
You are my guide, whether must I, Butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Toward Wakefield, where my masters living lies.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Toward Wakefield where thy master we will attend,
When things are at the worst, it is hopped they will mend.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How now sister, no further forward on your journey yet?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: When grief is before one, who would go on to grief,
I would rather turn me back to find some comfort.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: And that way sorrows hurtfuller than this,
My Brother having brought unto a grave,
That murthered body whom he called his wife,
And spent so many tears upon her Hearse,
As would have made a Tyrant to relent,
Then kneeling at her Coffin, thus he vowed,
From thence he never would embrace your bed.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The more Fool he.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Never from hence acknowledge you his wife,
When others strive to enrich their fathers name,
It should be his only aim, to beggar his,
To spend their means, and in his only pride,
Which with a sigh confirmed, he is rid to London,
Vowing a course, that by his life so foul
Men never should join the hands, without the soul.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: All is but grief, and I am armed for it.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: We will bring you on your way in hope that is strong
Time may at length make strait. what yet is wrong.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: He is our own, he is our own, Come, let us make use of his wealth, as the snow of Ice: Melt it, melt it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But art sure he will hold his meeting.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: As sure as I am now, and was dead drunk last night.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why then so sure will I be arrested by a couple of Sergeants, and fall into one of the unlucky Cranks about Cheapside, called Counters.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Withal, I have provided Mister Grype the Usurer, who upon the instant will be ready to step in, charge the Sergeants to keep thee fast, and that now he will have his five hundred pounds, or thou shalt rot for it.

sp.speaker: Went:
sp.p: When it follows, young Scarborow shall be bound for the one: then take up as much more, we share the one half, and help him to be drunk with the other.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, dost laugh Franke?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To see that we and Usurers line by the fall of young heirs as swine by the dropping of Acorns. But he is come. Where be these Rogues? shall we have no attendance here?

sp.speaker: Scarb.
sp.p: Good day Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
A thousand good days, my noble Bully, and as many good fortunes as there were Grasshoppers in Egypt, and that is covered
over with good luck: but Nouns, Pronouns, and Participles. Where be these Rogues here: what, shall we have no Wine here?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Anon, anon, sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Anon, goodman Rascal, must we stay your leisure? give it us by and by, with a pox to you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O, do not hurt the fellow?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Hurt him, hang him, Scrape-trencher, star-warren, Wine spiller, mettle-clancer, Rogue by generation. Why, dost hear Will? If thou dost not use these Grape-spillers as you do their pottle-pots, quoit them down stayres three or four times at a supper, they will grow as saucy with you as Sergeants, and make bills more unconscionable than Tailors.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here is the pure and neat grape Gent. I hate for you.

sp.speaker: Ilford.
sp.p: Fill up: what have you brought here, goodman rogue?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: The pure element of Claret sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Have you so, and did not I call for Rhenish you Mongrel?

div.stage: Throws the wine in the Drawers face.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Thou needst no wine, I prithee be more mild?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Be mild in a Tavern, it is treason to the red Lettuce, enemy to their sign post, and slave to humour:
sp.l: Prithee, let us be mad,
Then fill our heads with wine, till every pate be drunk,
Then piss in the street, Jostle all you meet, and with a Punk,
As thou wilt do now and then: Thank me thy good
Master, that brought thee to it.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Nay, he profits well, but the worst is he will not swear yet

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Do not belie me: If there be any good in me that is the best: Oaths are necessary for nothing, They pass out of a man's mouth, like smoke through a chimney, that files all the way it goes.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why then I think Tobacco be a kind of swearing, for it furs our nose pockily.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: But come, let us drink ourselves into a stomach afore supper.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Agreed. I will begin with a new health. Fill up.

l.hi: To them that make Land fly,
By wine, whores, and a Die.
To them that pay for clothes,
Care not from whom they get,
So they may be in debt:
We will hold him like this Glass,
And not a mate for us.

sp.p: Drink round my hearts.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: An excellent health.
Master Ilford, there is a couple of strangers beneath desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What beards have they? Gentleman-like-beards, or broker-like-beards?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I am not so well acquainted with the Art of Facemending sir: but they would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I will go down to them.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Do: and we will stay here and drink Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Scarb.
sp.l: Thus like a Fever that doth shake a man
From strength to weakness, I consume myself:
I know this company, their custom vild,
Hated, abhorred of good-men, yet like a child
By reasons rule instructed how to know
Evil from good, I to the worser go.
Why do you suffer this, you upper powers,
That I should surfeit in the sin I taste, have sense to feele my mischief, yet make waste
Of heaven and earth:
Myself will answer, what myself doth ask?
who once doth cherish sin, begets his shame,
For vice being fostered once, comes Impudence,
Which makes men count sin, Custom, not offence,
When all like me, their reputation blot,
Pursuing evil, while the good is forgot.

div.stage: Enter Ilford led in by a couple of Sergeants, and Gripe the Vsurer.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Nay, never strive, we can hold you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Aye, me, and any man else, if he fall into your Clutches: Let go your tugging, as I am a Gentleman, I will be your true prisoner.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: How now: what is the matter Franke?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I am fallen into the hands of Sergeants, I am arrested.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: How, arrest a Gentleman in our company?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Put up, put up, for sins sake put up, let us not all sup in the Counter tonight, let me speak with master Gripe the Creditor.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Well: what say you to me Sir?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You have arrested me here master Gripe.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Not I Sir, the Sergeants have.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But at your suit master Gripe: yet hear me, as I am a Gent.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I rather you could say as you were an honest man, and then I might believe you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Yet hear me.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Hear me no hearings, I lent you my money for good will.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And I spent it for mere necessity, I confess I owe you five hundred pound, and I confess I owe not a penny to any man, but he would be glad to hate: my bond you have already master Gripe If you will, now take my word.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Word me no words: Officers look to your prisoner: If you cannot either make me present payment, or put me in security such as I shall like too.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Such as you shall like too: what say you to this young Gent. He is the wigeon that we must feed upon.

sp.speaker: Grip.
Ilf.
sp.p: I would be ashamed any man should say so by me, that I have had dealings withal: But my enforced friends, wilt please you but to retire into some small distance, whilst I descend with a few words to these Gentlemen, and I will commit myself into your hands immediately.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Well sir we will wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
Gentlemen I am to profer some conference, and in especially to you master Scarborrow, our meeting here for your mirth hath proved to me thus adverse, that in your companies I am Arrested: How ill it will stand with the flourish of your reputations when men of rank and note communicate, that I Franke Ilforde, Gentleman. whose Fortunes may transcend, to make ample Gratuities
future, and heap satisfaction for any present extension of his friends kindness, was Enforced from the Mitre in Bredstreet, to the Counter in the Poultry: for mine own part, if you shall think it meet, and that it shall accord with the state of gentry, to submit myself from the feather bed in the Masters side, or the Flock-bed in the Knights ward, to the straw-bed in the hole, I shall buckle to my heels instead of guilt spurs, the armour of patience, and do it.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Come, come, what a pox need all this, this is Mellis Flora, the sweetest of the honey, he that was not made to fat Cattle, but to feed Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: You wear good clothes.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Are well descended.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Keep the best company.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Should regard your credit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Stand not upon it, be bound, be bound.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Ye are richly married.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Love not your wife.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Have store of friends.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Who shall be your heir.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: The son of some slave.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Some groom.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Some Horse-keeper.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Stand not upon it, be bound, be bound.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Well at your Importance, for once I will stretch my purse who is born to sink, as good this way as worse.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Now speaks my Bully like a Gentleman of worth.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Of merit.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Fit to be regarded.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: That shall command our souls.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Our swords.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To feed upon you as Pharoes lean kine did upon the fat.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Master Gripe is my bond currant for this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good security you Egyptian Grasshopper, good security?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: And for as much more kind Master Scarborrow.
Provided that men mortal as we are,
May have.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: May have security.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Your bond with land conveyed, which may assure me of mine own again.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You shall be satisfied, and I will become your debtor, for full five hundred more than he doth owe you.
sp.l: This night we sup here, bear us company,
And bring your Counsel, Scrivener, and the money with you,
Where I will make as full assurance as in the Law you would wish.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I take your word Sir,
And so discharge you of your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why then let us come and take up a new room, the infected hath spit in this.
sp.l: He that hath store of Coin, wants not a friend,
Thou shalt receive sweet rogue, and we will spend.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: Brother, you see the extremity of want
Enforceth us to question for our own,
The rather that we see, not like a Brother
Our Brother keeps from us to spend on other.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: True, he has in his hands our portions, the patrimony which our Father gave us, with which he lies fatting himself with Sack and sugar in the house, and we are fain to walk with lean purses abroad. Credit must be maintained which will not be without money, Good clothes must be had, which will not be without money, company must be kept which will not be without money, all which we must have, and from him we will have money.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Besides, we have brought our sister to this Town,
That she herself having her own from him,
Might bring herself in Court to be preferred,
Under some Noble personage, or else that he
Whose friends are great in Court, by his late match,
As he is in nature bound, provide for her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And he shall do it brother, though we have waited at his lodging, longer than a Tailors bill on a young Knight for an old reckoning, without speaking with him, here we know he is, and we will call him to parley.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Yet let us do it in mild and gentle terms,
Fair words perhaps may sooner draw our own,
Than rougher courses by which his mischief grown.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Anon, anon, look down into the Dolphin there.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Here comes a drawer we will question him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Do you hear my friend, is not master Scarborrow here?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here sir, what a jest is that, where should he be else, I would have you well know my master hopes to grow rich before he leaves him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: How long hath he continued here since he came hither.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Faith Sir not so long as Noah's flood, yet long enough to have drowned up the livings of three Knights, as Knights goes nowadays, some month or there abouts.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Time ill consumed to ruinate our house,
But what are they that keep him company?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Pitch, Pitch, but I must not say so, but for your further satisfaction, did you ever see a young whelp and a Lion play together.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Such is master Scarborrows company
Within Oliver.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon, look down to the Pomegranate there.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I prithee say here is them would speak with him.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I will do your message: Anon, anon there.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: This fool speaks wiser than he is aware,
young heirs left in this town where sins so rank,
And prodigals gape to grow fat by them,
Are like young whelps thrown in the Lions den,
who play with them awhile, at length devour them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Who is there would speak with me?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Your Brothers, who are glad to see you well.

sp.speaker: Scar,
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: It is not your riot, that we hear you use,
(With such as waste their goods, as Time the world
With a continual spending, nor that you keep
The company of a most Leprous route,
Consumes your bodies wealth, infects your name
With such Plague-sores, that had you reasons eye,
It would make you sick, to see you visit them)
Hath drawn us, but our wants to crave the dew
Our father gave, and yet remains with you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Our Birth-right good brother, this Town craves maintenance,
silk stockings must be had, and we would be loath our heritage should be arraigned at the Vintners bar, and so condemned to the Vintners box, though while you did keep house, we had some Belly-timber at your Table, or so, yet we would have you think, we are your Brothers, yet no Esaus to sell our patrimony for Porridge.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: So, so, what hath your coming else?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: With us our sister joins in our request,
Whom we have brought along with us to London,
To have her portion, wherewith to provide,
An honoured service, or an honest bride.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: So, then you two my Brothers, and she my sister, come not as in duty you are bound, to an elder brother, out of Yorkshire to see us, but like leaches to suck from us.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: We come compelled by want to crave our own.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Sir, for your own, then thus be satisfied,
Both hers and yours were left in trust with me,
And I will keep it for ye: Must you appoint us,
Or what we please to like mixed with reproof,
You have been too saucy both, and you shall know,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We do but crave our own.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Your own sir: what is your own?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Our portions given us by our fathers will,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Which here you spend.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Consume?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ways worse than ill.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, Wil: prithee come away, we have a full gallon of Sack stays in the fire for thee, thou must pledge it to the health of a friend of thine.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What dost think these are Franke?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: They are Fiddlers I think, if they be, I prithee send them into the next room, and let them scrape there, and we will send to them presently.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p:
They are my brothers Franke, come out of Yorkeshire, To the Tavern here, to ask their portions:
they call my pleasures, riots, my company Leprous, and like a school boy, they would tutor me?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, thou shouldst have done well to have bound them prentices when they were young, they would have made a couple of saucy Tailors.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Tailors?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I Bird-lime: Tailors: Tailors are good men, and in the Term time they wear good Clothes. Come, you must learn more manners, stand at your Brothers back, as to shift a Trencher neatly, and take a Cup of Sack, and a Capons leg contentedly.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are a slave
That feeds upon my brother like a fly,
Poisoning where thou dost suck.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O, to my grief I speak it, you shall find,
There is no more difference in a Tavern-haunter
than is between a Spittle and a Beggar.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou workest on him like Tempests on a ship.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And he the worthy Traffic that doth sink.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou makest his name more loathsome than a grave.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Livest like a Dog, by vomit,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Die a slave?

div.stage: Heere they draw. Wentlo, and Bartley come in, and the two Vintners boyes, with Clubbes. All set vpon the two Brothers. Butler, Scarborrows man comes in, stands by, sees them fight takes part with neyther.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Do, fight: I love you all well, because you were my old masters sons, but I will neither part you, nor be partaker with you. I come to bring my mast, news, he hath two sons born at a birth in Yorkshire, and I find him together by the ears with his brothers in a Tavern in London. Brother and brother at odds, it is naught: sure, it was not thus in the days of charity. What is this world like to? Faith just like an Innkeepers Chamber-pot, receives all waters, good and bad, It had need of much scouring. My old mast kept a good house, and twenty or thirty tall sword and Buckler men about him, and i'faith his son differs not much, he will have mettle too, though he hath not store of Cutlers blades, he will have plenty of Vintners pots. His father kept a good house for honest men,
his Tenants, that brought him in part, and his son keeps a bawdy house with Knaves that help to consume all. It is but the change of time: why should any man repine at it: Crickets, good living, and lucky worms, were wont to feed, sing, and rejoice in the fathers chimney, and now Carrion Crows builds in the sons Kitchen, I could be sorry for it, but I am too old to weep. Well then, I will go tell him news of his off-springs.

div.stage: Enter the two brothers, Thomas and Iohn Scarborrow hurt, and sister.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Alas good Brothers, how came this mischance?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Our portions, our brother hath given us our portions sister, hath he not?

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: He would not be so monstrous I am sure.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Excuse him not, he is more degenerate,
Than greedy Vipers that devour their mother,
They eat on her but to preserve themselves,
And he consumes himself, and Beggars us.
A Tavern is his Inn, where amongst Slaves,
He kills his substance, making pots the graves
To bury that which our forefathers gave.
I asked him for our portions, told him that you
Were brought to London, and we were in want,
Humbly we craved our own, when his Reply
Was, he knew none we had, beg, starve, or die.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: Alas what course is left for us to live by then?

sp.speaker: Tho
sp.l: In troth sister, we two to beg in the fields,
And you to betake yourself to the old trade,
Filling of small Cans in the suburbs.

sp.speaker: Sist
sp.l: Shall I be left then like a common road,
That every beast that can but pay his toll
May travel over, and like to Chamomile,
Flourish the better being trodden on.

sp.speaker: But,
sp.p: Well I will not curse him: he seeds now upon Sack and Anchovies with a pox to him: but if he be not fain before he dies to eat Acorns, let me live with nothing but pollard, and my mouth be made a Cooking stool for every scold to set her tail on.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How now Butler, what is the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Your brother means to lame as many as he can, that
is a beggar himself, many live with him in the Hospital. His wife sent me out of Yorkshire, to tell him, that God had blessed him with two sons, he bids a plague of them, a vengeance of her, crosses me over the pate, and sends me to the Surgeons to seek salve: I looked at least he should have given me a brace of Angels for my pains.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Thou hast not lost all thy longing, I am sure he hath given thee a cracked crown.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A plague on his fingers, I cannot tell, he is your Brother and my master, I would be loath to Prophecy of him, but whosoever doth curse his Children being Infants, ban his wife lying in child-bed, and beats his man brings him news of it, they may be born rich, but they shall live Slaves, be Knaves, and die Beggars.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Did he do so.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Guess you, he bid a plague of them, a vengeance on her, and sent me to the Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: Why then I see there is no hope of him. Some husbands are respectless of their wives,
During the time that they are issueless,
But none with Infants blessed, can nourish hate,
But love the mother for the children's sake.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: But he that is given over unto sin,
Leproused therewith without, and so within,
O Butler, we were issue to one father?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: And he was an honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Whose hopes were better than the sun he left,
Should set so soon, unto his houses shame.
He lives in Taverns, spending of his wealth,
And here his Brothers and distressed Sister,
Not having any means to help us with.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Not a Scots Bauble (by this hand) to bless us with.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And not content to riot out his own,
But he detains our portions: suffers us
In this strange Air, open to every wrack,
Whilst he in riot swims to be in lack.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: The more is the pity.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: I know not what course to take me to,
Honesty fain would live: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sooth I will tell you, your brother hath hurt us,
We three will hurt you, and then go all to a spittle together.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: Jest not at her, whose burden is too grievous,
But rather lend a means how to relieve us.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well I do pity you, and the rather because you sale, you would fain live honest and want means for it, for I can tell you it is as strange here to see a maid fair, poor, and honest, as to see a Collier with a clean face. Maids here do live (especially without maintenance)
sp.l: Like Mice going to a trap,
They nibble long, at last they get a clap.
sp.p: Your father was my good Benefactor, and gave me a house whilst I live to put my head in: for I would be loath then to see his only daughter, for want of means, turn punk, I have a drift to keep you honest. Have you a care to keep yourself so, yet you shall not know of it, for women's tongues are like sieves, they will hold nothing, they have power to vent. You two will further me

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: In anything good honest Butler.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: If it be to take a purse I will be one.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Perhaps thou speakest righter than thou art aware of: well, as chance it, I have received my wages: there is forty shillings for you, I will set you in a lodging, and till you hear from us, let that provide for you, we will first to the surgeons,
sp.l: To keep you honest, and to keep you brave,
For once an honest man, will turn a Knave.

div.stage: Enter Scarborrow hauing a Boy carrying a Torch with him, Ilford Wentlo, and Barley.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Boy, bear the Torch fair: Now am I armed to fight with a Wind-mill, and to take the wall of an Emperor: Much drink, no money: A heavy head, and a light pair of heels.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: O, stand man?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I were an excellent creature to make a Punk of, I should down with the least touch of a knaves finger, thou hast made a good night of this: What hast won Franke?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A matter of nothing, some hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p:
This is the hell of all gamesters, I think when they are at play, the board eats up the money: For if there be five hundred pound lost, there is never but a hundred pounds won. Boy, take
the wall of any man, and yet by light, such deeds of darkness may not be.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: What dost mean by that Will?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: To save charge, and walk like a Fury with a fire-brand in my hand, everyone goes by the light, and we will go by the smoke.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Boy, keep the Wall: I will not budge for any man, by these Thumbs, and the paring of the Nails shall stick in thy teeth not for a world.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Who is this, young Scarborrow?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The man that the Mare rid on.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Is this the reverence that you owe to me?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You should have brought me up better.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That vice should thus transform man to a beast.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Go to, your names Lord, I will talk with you when you are out of debt and have better clothes.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I pity thee even with my very soul.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Pity in thy throat, I can drink Muscadine and Eggs, and Mulled sack, do you hear: you put a piece of turned stuff upon me, but I will

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What will you do Sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Piss in thy way, and that is no slander.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Your sober blood will teach you otherwise.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.p: My honoured Lord, you are happily well met,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Ill met to see your Nephew in this case,
More like a brute Beast, than a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: S. wil.
sp.l: Fie: Nephew, shame you not thus to transform yourself?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Can your nose smell a Torch.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Be not so wild, it is thine Uncle Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Why then it is the more likely it is my Fathers brother.

sp.speaker: sir wil.
