sp.l: Shame to our name, to make thyself a Beast,
Thy body worthy born, and thy youths breast
Styled in due time for better discipline.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Thyself new married to a Noble house,
Rich in possessions, and Posterity,
Which should call home thy unstaid affections.

sp.speaker: S. will.
sp.l: Where thou makest havoc.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Riot, spoil, and waste,

sp.speaker: Syr willi,
sp.l: Of what thy father left.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And livest disgraced.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I will send you shorter to heaven, than you came to the earth, do you Catechise? Do you Catechise?

div.stage: He drawes and strikes at them.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Hold, hold, do you draw upon your uncle?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Pox of that Lord,
We will meet at Mitre, where we will sup down sorrow,
We are drunk tonight, and so we will be tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Why now I see: what I heard of, I believed not,
Your kinsman lives.

sp.speaker: S. wil.
sp.p: Like to a swine.

sp.speaker: Lo,
sp.l: A perfect Epithet he feeds on draff,
And wallows in the mire, to make men laugh,
I pity him.

sp.speaker: Sir wil.
sp.l: No pity is fit for him.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Yet we will advise him.

sp.speaker: Syr wil.
sp.l: He is my kinsman.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Being in the pit where many do fall in,
We will both comfort him, and counsel him.

div.stage: Anoyse within, crying, Follow, follow, follow: Then enter Butler, Thomas and Iohn Scarborrow with money bagges.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What shall we do now Butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A man had better line a good handsome pair of gallows before his time, than be born to do these sucklings good, their mothers milk not wrung out of their nose yet, they know no more how to behave themselves in this honest and needful calling of Purse-taking, than I do to piece stockings.

div.stage: within. This way, This way, this way.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: 'sfoot what shall we do now?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: See if they do not quake like a trembling. Asp-leaf, and look more miserable than one of the wicked Elders pictured in the painted cloth, should they but come to the credit to be arraigned for their valour, before a worshipful bench, their very looks would hang them, and they were indicted but for stealing of Eggs.

div.stage: within. Follow, follow, this way follow.

sp.speaker: Tho:
sp.p: Butler.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Honest Butler.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p:
Squat heart squat, creep me into these Bushes,
lie me as close to the ground as you would do to a wench.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How good Butler, show us how.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: By the Moon patroness of all purse-takers, who would be troubled with such Changelings, squat heart squat.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Thus Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I so suckling, so, stir not now, If the peering Rogues chance to go over you, yet stir not younger Brothers call you them and have no more forecast, I am ashamed of you, these are such whose fathers had need leave them money, even to make them ready withal, for by this hilts, they have not wit to button their sleeves without teaching, close, squat close. Now if the lot of hanging do fall to my share, so, then the Fathers old man drops for his young masters. If it chance it chances and when it chances, heaven and the Sheriff send me a good rope, I would not go up the lather twice for anything, in the mean time preventions, honest preventions do well, off with my skin, so you on the ground, and I to this tree to escape the Gallows.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Do follow, if I do not deceive you, I will bid a pox of this wit, and hang with a good grace.

div.stage: Enter Sir Iohn Harcop with two or three other with him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Up to this wood they took, search near my friends, I am this morn robbed of three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I am sorry there was not four to have made even money now by the Devils horns, it is Sir Iohn Harcop.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Leave not a bush unbear, nor tree unsearched, as sure as I was robbed the thieves went this way.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: There is Nobody I perceive but may lie at sometime for one of them climbed this ways.
Stand, I hear a voice, and here is an Owl in an Ivy bush.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: You lie, it is an old Serving-man in a Nut-tree.
Sirrah, sir, what make you in that tree.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Gathering of Nuts, that such fools as you are may crack the shells, and I eat the kernels.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What fellow is that?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Harcop, my Noble Knight, I am glad of your good health, you hear your Age fair, you keep a good house, I have fed at your board, and been drunk in your buttery.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: But sirrah: what made you in that tree?
My man and I at foot of yonder hill
Were by three knaves robbed of three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A shrewd loss byrlady sir, but your good worship may now see the fruit of being miserable: You will ride but with one man to save horse meat and man's meat at your Inn at night, and lose three hundred pound in a morning.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sirrah, I say I have lost three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And I say sir, I wish all miserable knights might be served so: For had you kept half a dozen tall fellows, as a man of your coat should do, they would have helped now to keep your money.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But tell me sir, why lurked you in that tree?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Marry, I will tell you sir, Coming to the top of the hill where you (Right worshipful) were robbed at the bottom, and seeing some a scuffling together, my mind strait gave me there were knaves abroad. Now sir, I knowing myself to be old, tough, and unwieldy, not being able to do as I would, as much as to say, Rescue you (right Worshipful,) I like an honest man, one of the Kings liege people, and a good subject

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He says well Sir.

Got me up to the top of that tree: The tree (if it could speak) would bear me witness, that there I might see which way the knaves took, then to tell you of it, and you right worshipfully to send hue to cry after them.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Was it so.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Nay it was so sir.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay then I tell thee they took into this wood.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And I tell thee (setting thy worships. knighthood aside) he lies in his throat that says so: Had not one of them a white Frock? Did they not bind your worships knighthood by the thumbs? then faggoted you and the fool your man, back to back.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He says true.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why then so truly, came not they into this wood, but took over the Lawns, and left Winno steeple on the left hand.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It may be so, by this they are out of reach, Well, farewell it.

sp.speaker: But,
sp.p: Ride with more men, good knight.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It shall teach me wit.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: So, If this be not played a weapon beyond a Scholars Prize, let me be hist at. Now to the next. Come out you Hedgehogs?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: O Butler, thou deservest to be chronicled for this.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Do not belie me, If I had my right I deserve to be hanged for it. But come, Down with your dust, our mornings purchase.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Here it is, Thou hast played well, Thou deservest two shares in it.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Three hundred pound: A pretty breakfast: Many a man works hard all his days and never sees half the money. But come, Though it be badly got, it shall be better bestowed. But do ye hear Gallants, I have not taught you this trade to get your livings by. Use it not, for if you do, though I scaped by the Nut tree, be sure you will speed by the Rope: But for your pains at this time, There is a hundred pounds for you, how you shall bestow it, I will give you instructions. But do you hear, Look you go not to your Gilles, your Punks, and your Cock-tricks with it, If I hear you do: as I am an honest thief, though I helped you now out of the Briars, I will be a means yet to help you to the Gallows. How the rest shall be employed I have determined, and by the way I will make you acquainted with it.
sp.l: To steal is bad, but taken where is store,
The faults the less, being done to help the pore

div.stage: Enter Ilford, wentloe, Bartley. Ilford hauing a letter in his hande.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sure I have a said my prayers, and lived virtuously of late, that this good fortunes befallen me. Look Gallants: I am sent for to come down to my Fathers burial.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: But dost mean to go?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Troth no, I will go down to take possession of his land, let the country bury him and the will: I will stay here a while, to save charge at his funeral.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: And how dost feel thyself Franke, now thy father is dead?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: As I did before, with my hands, how should I feel myself else? But I will tell you news Gallants.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: What is that? Dost mean now to serve God?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Faith partly, for I intend shortly to go to Church, and from thence do faithful service to one woman.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Good, I have met my flesh-hooks together.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: What, Dost mean to be married?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Aye Mongrel, Married.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: That is a bait for me.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I will now be honestly married.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: It is impossible, for thou hast been a whoremaster this seven year.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: It is no matter, I will now marry, And to some honest woman too, and so from hence her vertues shall be a countenance to my vices.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: What shall she be, prithee?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: No Lady, no widow, nor no waiting gentlewoman, for under protection
Ladies may lard their husbands heads, Widows will Woodcocks make, and chambermaids of serving-men learn that, they will never forsake.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Who wilt thou wed then, prithee?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To any maid, so she be fair: To any maid, so she be rich To any maid so she be young: and to any maid

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: So she be honest.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Faith, it is no great matter for her honesty, for in these days, that is a Dowry out of request.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: From these Crabs will I gather sweetness: wherein I will imitate the Bee, that sucks her honey, not from the sweetest flowers, but Timb the bitterest: So these having been the means to beggar my master, shall be the helps to relieve his brothers and sister.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To whom shall I now be a suitor?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Fair fall ye Gallants.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, if she be fair she shall fall sure enough. Butler, how Is it good Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Will you be made gallants?

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Aye, but not willingly Cuckolds, though we are now talking about wives.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Let your wives agree of that after, will you first be richly married?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How Butler: richly married?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Rich in beauty, rich in purse, rich in virtue, rich in all things. But Mum, I will say nothing, I know of two or three rich heirs. But Cargo, my fiddlestick cannot play without Rosin: Avaunt.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Butler.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Dost not know me Butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: For Kex, dried Kex, that in summer have been so liberal to fodder other men's cattle, and scarce have enough to keep your own in Winter. Mine are precious Cabinets, and must have precious Jewels put into them, and I know you to he merchants of Stockfish, and not men for my market: Then vanish.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Come, ye old mad-cap you, what need all this? Cannot a man have been a little whoremaster in his youth, but you must upbraid him with it, and tell him of his defects, which when he is married, his wife shall find in him? Why my fathers dead man now, who by his death has left me the better part of a thousand a year.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Tut, she of Lancashire has fifteen hundred.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Let me have her then, good Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And then she the bright beauty of Leystershire, has a thousand, nay thirteen hundred a year, at least.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Or let me have her, honest Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Besides, she the most delicate, sweet countenanced, black browed gentlewoman in Northamptonshire, in substance equals the best of them.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Let me have her then.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Or I.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Or I, good Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You were best play the parts of right fools, and most desperate whoremasters, and go together by the ears for them ere ye see them. But they are the most rare featured, well faced, excellent spoke, rare qualitied, virtuous, and worthy to be admired gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And rich Butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: (Aye that must be one, though they want all the rest) And rich Gallants, as are from the utmost parts of Asya, to these present confines of Europe.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: And wilt thou help us to them Butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Faith, it is to be doubted, for precious pearl will hardly be bought without precious stones, and I think there is scarce one indifferent one to be found, betwixt you three: yet since there is some hope ye may prove honest, as by the death of your fathers.
Fathers you are proved rich, walk severally, for I knowing you all three to be covetous Tug-muttons will not trust you with the sight of each others beauty but will severally, talk with you, and since you have deigned in this needful portion of wedlock to be ruled by me Butler, will most bountifully provide wives for you generally.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Why that honestly said.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why so, and now first to your Sir Knight

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Godamercy.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You see this couple of abominable Woodcocks hear.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A pox on them, absolute Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You heard me tell them, I had Intelligence to give of three Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Now indeed Sit I have but the performance of one.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And her I do intend for you, only for you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Honest Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Now sir, she being but lately come to this town, and so nearly watched by the jealous eyes of her friends, she being a Rich heir, lest she should be stolen away by some dissolute Prodigal, or desperate estated spend thrift, as you have been Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O but that is past Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: True I know it, and intend now but to make use of them, flatter with them with hopeful promises, and make them needful instruments.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To help me to the wench,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You have hit it which thus must be effected, first by keeping close your purpose.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Also concealing from them, the lodging beauty and riches of your new, but admirable Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Of which your following happiness, if they should know either in envy of your good, or hope of their own advancement they would make our labours known to the gentlewoman's Uncles, and so our benefit be frustrate.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Admirable Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Which done, all is but this, being as you shall be brought into her company, and by my praising your vertues you get possession of her Love, one morning step to the tower, or to make all sure, hire some stipendary priest for money: for Money in these days, what will not be done, and what will not a man do for a rich wife, and with him make no more ado but marry hit in her lodging and being married, he with her and spare not.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Do they not see us, do they not see us, let me kiss thee, let me kiss thee Butler, let but this be done, and all the benefit requital and happiness. I can promise thee for it, shall be this, I will be thy rich master, and thou shalt carry my purse.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Enough, meet me at her lodging some half an hour hence: hark she lies.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I hate.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Fail not.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Will I live.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I will but shift of these two Rhinoceros,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Wigeons, wigeons, a couple of gulls.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: With some discourse of hope to wive them two, and be with you straight.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Blessed day, my love shall be thy cushion honest Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: So now to my tother Gallants.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: O Butler, we have been in passion at thy tediousness,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why look you. I had all this talk for your good.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Hadst.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: For you know the knight is but a scurvy-proud-prating-prodigal, licentious unnecessary.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: An Ass, an Ass, an Ass.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Now you heard me tell him I had three Wenches in store,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And he would have had them all would he.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Hear me, though he may live to be an Ox, he had not now so much of the Goat in him, but only hopes for one of the three when indeed I have but two, and knowing you two be men of more virtue, and dearer in my respect intend them to be yours.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: We shall honour thee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: But how Butler.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p:
I am now going to their place of residence, situate in the choicest place in the City, and at the sign of the Wolf just against Gold-smiths-row
where you shall meet me, but ask not for me, only walk to and fro and to avoid suspicion you may spend some conference with the Shop-keepers wives, they have seats built a-purpose for such familiar entertainment, where from a bay window which is opposite, I will make you known to your desired beauties, commend the good parts you have.

sp.speaker: Went
sp.p: Bythe mass mine are very few.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And win a kind of desire, as women are soon won to make you be beloved where you shall first kiss, then Woe, at length Wed, and at last bed my Noble hearts.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: O Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Wenches bona robes, blessed beauties, without colour or counterfeit: Away, put on you best Clothes, get you to the Barbers, Curl up your hair, walk with the best struts you can, you shall see more at the Window, and I have vowed to make you.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Wilt thou.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Both Fools, and I will want of my wit but I will do it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: We will live together as fellows.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: As Brothers.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: As arrant knaves if I keep you company,
O, the most wretched season of this time,
These men like Fish, do swim within one stream,
Yet they would eat one another, making no Conscience
To drink with them they would poison, no offence,
Betwixt their thoughts and actions have control,
But headlong run, like an unbiased Bowl,
Yet I will throw them on, but like to him,
At play knows how to , and when to win.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O, are you come. And fit as I appointed: so, it is well, you know you knees, and have instructions how to bear yourselves: All, all is fit, play but your part, your states from hence are firm.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: What shall I term this creature not a man.

div.stage: Betwixt this Butler leads Ilford in.

sp.l: He is not of mortals temper but he is one,
Made all of goodness, though of flesh and bone,
O Brother, brother, but for that honest man,
As near to misery had been our breath,
As where the thundering pellet strikes is death.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Aye, my shift of shirts and change of cloths know it.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Well tell of him, like bells whose music rings
One Coronation day for joy of Kings,
That hath preserved their steeples not like towels,
That summons living tears for the dead souls,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Gods precious Sir, the hell Sir, even as you had new kissed, and were about to court her, if her Uncles be not come.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A plague on thee, spit out.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: But it is no matter Sir, stay you here in this upper chamber, and I will stay beneath with her, it is ten to one you shall hear them talk now, of the greatness of her possessions, the care they have to see her well bestowed, the admirableness of her vertues, all which for all their coming, shall be but happiness ordained for you, and by my means be your inheritance.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then thou wilt shift them away, and keep from the sight of them.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Have I not promised to make you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Thou hast.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Go to then, rest here with patience, and be confident in my trust, only in my absence, you may praise God for the blessedness you have to come, and say your prayers if you will, I will but prepare her heart for entertainment of your love, dismiss them, for your free access, and return straight.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Honest-blest-natural-friend, thou dealest with me like a Brother: Butler,
Sure heaven hath reserved this man to wear Grey-hairs to do me good, now will I listen, listen close, and suck in her Uncles words with a rejoicing ear,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: As we were saying Brother,
Where shall we find a husband for my Niece.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Marry she shall find one here though you little know it, thanks,
Thanks honest Butler.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: She is left rich in Money, Plate, and Jewels.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Comfort, comfort to my soul.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Hath all her manner houses richly furnished.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Good, good, I will find employment for them.

sp.speaker: With. But.
sp.l: Speak loud enough that he may hear you.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I take her state to be about a thousand pound a year,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And that which my father, hath left me, will make it about fifteen, hundred admirable.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: In debt to no man, then must our natural care be,
As she is wealthy to see her married well.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: And that she shall be as well as the priest can, he shall not,
Leave out a word of it.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I think she has.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: What in Gods name.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: About four thousand pound in her great chest.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: And I will find a vent for it I hope.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: She is virtuous, and she is fair.

sp.speaker: Ilf,
sp.l: If she were foul, being rich, I would be glad of her.

sp.speaker: But
sp.l: Pisht, pisht.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Come, we will go visit her, but with this care,
That to no spend-thrift we do marry her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
You may chance be deceived old gray-beards, hears he will spend some of it, thanks, thanks, honest Butler, now do I see the happiness of my future estate, I walk me as tomorrow, being the day after my marriage, with my fourteen men in Livery cloaks after me, and step to the wall in some chief street of the City, though I have no occasion to use it, that the Shop-keepers may take notice how many followers stand bare to me, and yet in this latter age, the keeping of men being not in request, I will turn my aforesaid fourteen into two Pages and two Coaches, I will get myself into grace at Court, run head-long into debt, and then look scurvily upon the City, I will walk you into the presence in the afternoon having put on a richer suit, than I wore in the morning, and call boy or straw, I will have the grace of some great Lady though I pay for it, and at the next Triumphs run a Tilt, that when I run my course, though I break not my lance: she may whisper to herself, looking upon my smell, well run my knight
I will now keep great horses, scorning to have a Quean to keep me, indeed I will practise all the Gallantry in use, for by a Wife comes all my happiness.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Now sir, you have heard her Uncles, and how do you like them.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: O But. they have made good thy words, and I am ravished with them.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: And having seen and kissed the gentlewoman. how do you like her?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O Butler beyond discourse, she is Paragon for a Prince, then a fit Implement for a Gentleman, beyond my Element.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well then, since you like her, and by my means, she shall like you, nothing rests now but to have you married.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: True Butler, but withal to have her portion.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Tut, that is sure yours when you are married once, for it is hers by Inheritance, but do you love her?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, with my soul.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Have you sworn as much.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To thee, to her, and have called heaven to witness.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: How shall I know that.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Butler, here I protest, make vows Irrevocable.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Upon your knees.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Upon my knees, with my heart, and soul I love her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Will live with her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Will live with her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Marry her and maintain her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Marry her and maintain her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: For her forsake all other women.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay for her forswear all other women.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: In all degrees of Love.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: In all degrees of Love, either to Court, kiss, give private favours, or use private means, I will do nothing that married men being close whoremasters do, so I may have her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And yet you having been an open whoremaster, I will not believe you till I hear you swear as much in the way of contract to herself, and call me to be a witness.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: By heaven, by earth, by Hell, by all that man can swear, I will so I may have her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Enough.
Thus at first sight, rash men to women swear,
When such oaths broke, heaven grieves and sheds a tear:
But she is come, ply her, ply her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Kind Mistress, as I protested, so again I vow, I faith I love you.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: And I am not Sir so uncharitable,
To hate the man that loves me.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Love me then,
The which loves you as Angels loves good men,
who wish them to live with them ever,
In that high bliss whom hell cannot dissever.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will steal away and leave them, so wise men do,
Whom they would match, let them have leave to woe.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Mistress I know your worth is beyond my desert, yet by my praising of your virtues, I would not have you as women use to do, become proud.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: None of my affections are prides children, nor a kin to them

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Can you love me them?

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: I can, for I love all the world, but am in love with none.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Yet be in love with me, let your affections
Combine with mine, and let our souls
Like Turtles have a mutual Sympathy,
who love so well, that they together die,
Such is my life, who covets to expire,
If it should lose your love.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: May I believe you?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Introth you may,
Your life is my life, your death my dying day.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Sir the commendations I have received from Butler of your birth and worth, together with the Judgment of mine own eye, bids me believe and love you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: O seal it with a kiss,
Blessed hour my life had never joy till this.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Here about is the house sure.

sp.speaker: Wentlo.
sp.p: We cannot mistake it, for here is the sign of the Wolf and the Bay-window.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What so close? It is well, I have shifted away your Uncles Mistress, but see the spite Sir Francis, if you same couple of Smell-smocks, Wentloe and Bartley, have not scented after us.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A pox on them, what shall we do then Butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What but be married straight man.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Aye but how Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
Ilf.
sp.p: Where, prithee Butler where?

sp.speaker: but.
sp.p: Where? But beneath in her Chamber. I have filled his hands with Coin, and he shall tie you fast with words, he shall close your hands in one, and then do clap yourself into her sheets and spare not.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O sweet.

sp.speaker: but.
sp.l: Down, down, it is the only way for you to get up.
Thus in this task, for others good I toil,
And she kind Gentlewoman weds herself,
Having been scarcely wooed, and ere her thoughts,
Have learned to love him, that being her husband,
She may relieve her, brothers in their wants,
She marries him to help her nearest kin,
I make the match, and hope it is no sin.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: 'sfoot it is scurvy Walking, for us so near the two Counters, would he would come once?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Mass he is yonder: Now Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O Gallants are you here, I have done wonders for you commended you to the Gentlewomen, who having taken note of your good legs, and good faces, have a liking to you, meet me beneath.

sp.speaker: both
sp.p: Happy Butler.

sp.speaker: but.
sp.l: They are yours, and you are theirs, meet me beneath I say.
By this they are wed, Aye and perhaps have bedded,
Now follows whether knowing she is poor,
He will swear he loved her as he swore before.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Ho Sirrah, who would have thought it, I perceive now a woman may be a maid, be married, and lose her maiden-head, and all in half and an hour, and how dost like me now wench.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: As doth befit your servant and your wife,
That owe you love and duty all my life.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And there shall be no Love lost, nor service neither, I will do thee service at board, and thou shalt do me service a bed: Now must I as young married men use to do, kiss my portion out of my young wife. Thou art my sweet Rogue, my Lamb, my Pigsny, my play-fellow, my pretty pretty anything, come a buss prithee, so it is my kind heart, and what is thou what now?

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Not till you tell me Sir,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I have got thee with Child in my Conscience, and like a kind Husband, methinks I breed it for thee. For I am already sick at my stomach and long extremely. Now must thou be my helpful Physician, and provide for me.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: Even to my blood,
What is mine is yours, to gain your peace or good.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What a kind soul is this, could a man have found a greater content in a wife, if he should have sought thorough the world for her: Prithee heart as I said, I long, and in good troth I do, and methinks thy first child will be born without a nose, if I lose my longing, it is but for a trifle too, yet methinks it will do me no good unless thou effect it for me. I could take thy keys myself, go into thy Closet, and read over the deeds and evidences of thy Land, and in reading over them, rejoice I had such blessed fortune to have so fair a wife with so much endowment, and then open thy Chests, and survey thy Plate, Jewels, Treasure. But a pox on it, all will do me no good, unless thou effect it for me.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: Sir I will show you all the wealth I have,
Of Coin, of Jewels, or Possessions,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good gentle heart, I will give thee another buss for that, for that give thee a new gown tomorrow morning, by this hand do thou but dream what stuff and what Fashion thou wilt have it on tonight.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: The land I can endow you with, is my Love,
The riches I possess for you is love,
A Treasure greater than is Land or Gold,
It cannot be forfeited, and it shall never be sold.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
Love I know that, and I will answer thee love for. Love in abundance: but come prithee come, let us see these deeds and evidences,
this Money, Plate, and Jewels, with ha thy Child born without a nose, if thou beest so careless, spare not, why my little frappet you, I heard thy Uncles talk of thy riches, that thou hadst hundreds a year, several Lord-ships, Manors Houles, Thousands of pounds in your great Chests, Jewels, Plate, and Rings in your little Box.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: And for that riches you did marry me.

sp.speaker: Ilf
sp.p: Troth I did, as nowadays Bachelors do swear I loved thee but indeed married thee for thy wealth.

sp.speaker: sist.
sp.l: Sir I beseech you say not your oaths were such,
So like false coin, being put unto the touch,
who bear a flourish in the outward show,
Of a true stamp, but truly are not so,
You swore me love, I gave the like to you,
Then as a ship being wedded to the sea,
Does either sail or sink even so must I,
You being the haven to which my hopes must she.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: True Chuck I am thy haven, and harbour too,
And like a ship I took thee, who brings home Treasure
As thou to me, the Merchant-venturer.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: What riches I am ballast with are yours.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: That is kindly said now,

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: If but with sand, as I am but with earth,
Being your right of right, you must receive me,
I have no other lading but my Love.
Which in abundance I will render you,
If other fraught you do expect my store,
I will pay you tears, my riches, are no more.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: How is this? how is this? I hope you do but Jest,

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: I am Sister to decayed Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: Whose substance your Enticements did consume.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Worse than an Ague.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: Which as you did believe so they supposed,
It was fitter for yourself than for another,
To keep the sister, had undone the brother.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
I am gulled by this hand. An old Cony-catcher, and beguiled; where the pox now are my two Coaches, choice of houses, several
suits, a plague on them, and I know not what: Do you hear Puppet, do you think you shall not be damned for this, to Cousin a Gentleman of his hopes, and compel yourself into Matrimony with a man, whether he will or no with you, I have made a fair match i'faith, will any man buy my commodity out of my hand, as God save me he shall have her for half the money she cost me.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: O, have we met you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: What, turned Micher, steal a wife, and not make your old friends acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A pox on her, I would you had her.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Well, God give you Joy, we can hear of your good fortune, now it is done, though we could not be acquainted with it aforehand.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: As that you have two thousand pound a year.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Two or three manor houses.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: A wife, fair, rich, and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Pretty i'faith, very pretty.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Store of Gold.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Plate in abundance.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Better, better, better.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: And so many Oxen, that their horns are able to store all the Cuckolds in your Country.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Do not make me mad good Gentlemen, do not make me mad, I could be made a Cuckold with more patience, than endure this.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: For we shall have you turn proud now, grow respectless of your Ancient acquaintance, why Butler told us of it: Who was the maker of the match for you?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A pox of his furtherance, Gentlemen as you are Christians, vex me no more, that I am married I confess, a plague of the Fates, that wedding and hanging comes by destiny, but for the riches she has brought, bear witness how I will reward her.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Whore, Aye and Jade, Witch, Ill-faced, stinking-breath, crooked-nose, worse than the Devil, and a plague on thee that ever I saw thee.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: A Comedy, a Comedy.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this, is this the mask after thy marriage.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O Gentlemen, I am undone, I am undone, for I am married, I that could not abide a Woman, but to make her a whore, hated all She-creatures, fair and poor, swore I would never marry but to one that was rich, and to be thus coney-catched. Who do you think this is Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Why your wife, Who should it be else?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That is my misfortune, that marrying her in hope she was rich, she proves to be the beggarly Sister to the more beggarly Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Aye, you may laugh, but she shall cry as well as I for it,

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Nay, do not weep.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: He does but counterfeit now to delude us, he has all her portion of Land, Coin, Plate, Jewels: and now dissembles thus lest we should borrow some Money of him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And you be kind Gentlemen lend me some, for having payed the Priest, I have not so much left in the world, as will hire me a horse to carry me away from her.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: But art thou thus gulled i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Are you sure you have eyes in your head.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: Why then, By her brothers setting one in my conscience, who knowing thee now to have somewhat to take to, by the death of thy father, and that he hath spent her portion, and his own possessions, hath laid this plot, for thee to marry her, and so he to be rid of her himself.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, that is without question, but I will be revenged of them both, for you Minx. Nay 'sfoot, give them me, or I will kick else.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Good, sweet.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sweet with a pox, you stink in my nose, give me your Jewels? Nay Bracelets too.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: O me, most miserable.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Out of my sight, Aye and out of my doors, for now, what is within this house is mine, and for your brother
sp.l: He made this match, in hope to do you good,
And I wear this for which, shall draw his blood.

sp.speaker: went.
sp.p: A brave resolution.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: In which we will second thee.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Away, whore, Out of my doors whore.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.l: O grief, that poverty should have that power to tear:
Men from themselves, though they wed, bed, and swear.

div.stage: Enter Thomas and Iohn Scarborrow, with Butler.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How now sister.

sp.speaker: sist.
sp.p: Undone, undone.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why Mistress, how is it? how is it?

sp.speaker: sist.
sp.p: My husband has forsook me.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O perjury.

sp.speaker: sist.
sp.p: Has taken my Jewels, and my Bracelets from me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Vengeance, I played the thief for the money that bought them.

sp.speaker: sist.
sp.p: Left me distressed, and thrust me forth a-doors.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Damnation on him, I will hear no more,
But for his wrong revenge me on my brother,
Degenerate, and was the cause of all,
He spent our portion, and I will see his fall.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: O but Brother.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Persuade me not.
All hopes are shipwrecked, misery comes on,
The comfort we did look from him is frustrate,
All means, all maintenance, but grief is gone.
And all shall end by his destruction.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: I will follow and prevent, what in this heat may happen,
His want makes sharpe his sword, too great is the ill,
If that one brother should another kill.

sp.speaker: But,
sp.l: And what will you do Mistress?

sp.speaker: sist.
sp.l: I will sit me down, sigh loud instead of words,
And wound myself with grief as they with swords.
And for the sustenance that I should eat,
I will feed on grief, it is woes best relished meat.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Good heart I pity you,
You shall not be so cruel to yourself,
I have the poor Serving-man's allowance,
Twelve pence a day to buy me sustenance,
One meal a day I will eat, the tother fast,
To give your wants relief. And Mistress
Be this some comfort to your miseries,
I will have thin cheeks, ere you shall have wet eyes.
What is prodigality? Faith like a Brush
That wears himself to flourish others clothes,
And having worn his heart even to the stump,
He is thrown away like a deformed lump.
O such am I, I have spent all the wealth
My ancestors did purchase, made others brave
In shape and riches, and myself a knave.
For though my wealth raised some to paint their door,
It is shut against me, saying I am but poor:
Nay, even the greatest arm, whose hand hath graced,
My presence to the eye of Majesty, shrinks back,
His fingers clutch, and like to lead,
They are heavy to raise up my state, being dead.
By which I find, spend thrifts, and such am I,
Like strumpets flourish, but are foul within,
And they like Snakes, know when to cast their skin.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Turn, draw, and die, I come to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: What is he that speaks? Like sickness: O is it you,
Sleep still, you cannot move me, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Think not my fury slakes so, or my blood
Can cool itself to temper by refusal,
Turn or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do not wish to kill thee like a slave,
That taps men in their cups, and broach their hearts,
Ere with a warning piece they have waked their ears,
I would not like to powder shoot thee down,
To a flat grave, ere thou hast thought to frown:
I am no Coward, but in manly terms,
And fairest oppositions vow to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: From whence proceeds this heat.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: From sparkles bred by thee, that like a villain.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I will hallow it in thine ears till thy soul quake to hear it,
That like a villain hast undone thy brothers.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Would thou wert not so near me: yet farewell.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By nature, and her laws make us a kin,
As near as are these hands, or sin to sin.
Draw and defend thyself, or I will forget
Thou art a man.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Would thou were not my Brother?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I disclaim them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Are we not off-spring of one parent wretch.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do forget it, pardon me the dead,
I should deny the pains you bid for me.
My blood grows hot for vengeance, thou hast spent
My lives revenues that our parents purchased.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O do not wrack me with remembrance on it.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou hast made my life a Beggar in this world,
And I will make thee bankrupt of thy breath:
Thou hast been so bad, the best I can give,
Thou art a Devil, not with men to live.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Then take a Devils payment.

div.stage: Heere they make a passe one vpon another, when at Scarborrowes backe. comes in Ilford, Wentloe, and Bartley.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He is here, draw Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Went. Bart.
sp.p: Die Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Girt round with death.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How set upon by three, 'sfoot fear not Brother, yon Cowards, three to one, slaves, worse than Fencers that wear long weapons. You shall be fought withal, you shall be fought withal.

div.stage: Here the Brothers ioyne, driue the rest out, and returne.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Brother I thank you, for you now have been
A patron of my life, forget the sin
I pray you, with my loose and wasteful hours,
Hath made against your Fortunes, I repent them,
And wish I could new joint and strength your hopes,
Though with indifferent ruin of mine own.
I have a many sins, the thought of which
Like finished Needles prick me to the soul,
But find your wrongs, to have the sharpest point.
If penitence your losses might repair,
You should be rich in wealth, and I in care.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do believe you Sir, but I must tell you,
Evils the which are against another done,
Repentance makes no satisfaction
To him that feels the smart. Our father sir,
Left in your trust my portion: you have spent it,
And suffered me (whilst you in riots house,
A drunken Tavern, spilled my maintenance
Perhaps upon the ground with overflown cups,
Like birds in hardest winter half starved, to fly)
And pick up any food, lest I should die.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: I prithee let us be at peace together.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: At peace for what? For spending my inheritance,
By yonder son that every soul has life by,
As sure as thou hast life I will fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I would not be moved unto it.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I will kill thee then, wert thou now clasped
Within thy mother, wife, or children's arms.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Wouldst homicide? art so degenerate?
Then let my blood grow hot.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: For it shall cool.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: To kill rather than be killed is manhoods rule.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Stay let not your wraths meet.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Heart, what makest thou here?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Say who are you, or you, are you not one,
That scarce can make a fit distinction
Betwixt each other. Are you not Brothers?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I renounce him.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Shalt not need.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Give way.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Have at thee,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: who stirs, which of you both hath strength within his arm
To wound his own breast, who is so desperate,
To damn himself by killing of himself,
Are you not both one flesh?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Heart, give me way.

sp.speaker: sca.
sp.l: Be not a bar betwixt us, or by my sword
I will mete thy grave out.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.l: O do, for Gods sake do?
It is happy death, if I may die and you
Not murther one another. O do but hearken,
When does the Sun and Moon born in one frame
Contend, but they breed Earthquakes in men's hearts:
When any star prodigiously appears,
Tell us it not fall of kings or fatal years.
And then if Brothers fight, what may men think,
Sin grows so high, it is time the world should sink.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: My heart grows cool again, I wish it not.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Stop not my fury, or by my life I swear,
I will reveal the robbery we have done,
And take revenge on thee,
That hinders me to take revenge on him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I yield to that, but never consent to this,
I shall then die as mine own, sin affords,
Fall by the law, not by my Brothers swords.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Then by that light that guides me here I vow,
I will straight to Sir Iohn Harcop, and make known
We were the two that robbed him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Prithee do.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Sin has his shame, and thou shalt have thy due.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Thus have I shown the nature of a Brother,
Though you have proved unnatural to me.
He is gone in heat to publish out the theft,
Which want and your unkindness forest us to,
If now I die that death and public shame,
Is a Corsive to your soul, blot to your name.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: O it is too true, there is not a thought I think,
But must partake thy griefs, and drink
A relish of thy sorrow and misfortune,
With weight of others tears I am over borne,
That scarce am Atlas to hold up mine own,
And all to good for me. A happy Creature
In my Cradle, and have made myself
The common curse of mankind by my life,
Undone my Brothers, made them thieves for bread,
And begot pretty children to live beggars,
O Conscience, how thou are stung to think upon it,
My Brothers unto shame must yield their blood,
My Babes at others stirrups beg their food,
Or else turn thieves too, and be choked for it,
Die a Dogs death, be perched upon a tree,
Hang betwixt heaven and earth, as fit for neither,
The curse of heaven that is due to reprobates,
Descends upon my Brothers, and my children,
And I am parent to it, Aye, I am parent to it.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Why starest thou, what is thy haste?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Here is fellows swarm like flies to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Snakes I think Sir, for they come with stings in their mouths, and their tongues are turned to teeth too: They claw Villainously, they have eat up your honest name, and honourable reputation by railing against you, and now they come to devour your possessions.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: In plainer Euargy, what are they, speak?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Mantichoras, monstrous beasts, enemies to mankind, that have double rows of teeth in their mouths. They are Usurers, they come yawning for money, and the Sheriff with them, is come to serve an extent upon you Land, and then cease on your body by force of execution, they have begirt the house round.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: So that the roof our Ancestors did build
For their sons comfort, and their wives for Charity,
I dare not to look out.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Besides Sir, here is your poor children.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Poor children they are indeed.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Come with fire and water: tears in their eyes, and burning grief in their hearts, and desire to speak with you.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Heap sorrow upon sorrow? Tell me, are
My brothers gone to execution?
For what I did, for every heinous sin,
Sits on his soul by whom it did begin.
And so did theirs by me. Tell me withal,
My children carry moisture in their eyes,
Whose speaking drops, say father, thus must we
Ask our relief, or die with infamy,
For you have made us beggars. Yet when thy tale has killed me
to give my passage comfort from this stage,
Say all was done by enforced marriage:
My grave will then be welcome.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: What shall we do sir?

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Do as the devil does, hate panther-mankind,
And yet I lie: for devils sinners love,
When men hate men, though good like some above.

div.stage: Enter Scarborrowes wife Katherine with two Children.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Your wife is come in sir.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Thou liest, I have not a wife. None can be called,
True man and wife, but those whom heaven installed. Say,

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: O my deer husband?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: You are very welcome, peace: we will have complement.
Who are you Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Sir your distressed wife, and these your children.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Mine? Where, how begot:
Prove me by certain instance that is divine,
That I should call them lawful, or they mine.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Were we not married sir?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: No, though we heard the words of Ceremony,
But had hands knit as felons that wear fetters
Forced upon them. For tell me woman,
Did ever my Love with sighs entreat thee mine,
Did ever I in willing conference,
Speak words, made half with tears that I did love thee.
Or was I ever
But glad to see thee as all Lovers are.
No, no, thou knowest I was not.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: O me.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: The more is the pity.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: But when I came to Church, I did there stand
All water, whose forest breach had drowned my Land,
Are you my wife, or these my children?
Why it is impossible, for like the skies,
Without the suns light, so look all your eyes,
Dark, Cloudy, thick, and full of heaviness,
Within my Country there was hope to see
Me and my issue to be like our fathers,
Upholders of our Country, all our life,
Which should have been, if I had wed a wife.
Where now,
As dropping leaves in Autumn you look all,
And I that should uphold you like to fall,

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: It was, nor, shall be my fault. Heaven bear me witness.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Thou liest? strumpet thou liest?

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: O Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Peace saucy Iacke, strumpet I say thou liest,
For wife of mine thou art not, and these thy Bastards
Whom I begot of thee, with this unrest,
That Bastards born, are born not to be Blessed

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: On me pour all your wrath, but not on them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: On thee, and them, for it is the end of lust,
To scourge itself, heaven lingering to be just:
Harlot.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Bastards.

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: What heart not pities this?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Even in your Cradle, you were accursed of heaven,
Thou an Adulteress in thy married arms.
And they that made the match, bawds to thy lust:
Aye, now you hang the head, shouldst have done so before,
Then these had not been Bastards, thou a whore.

sp.speaker: Bue.
sp.l: I cannot brook it no longer, Sir you do not well in this?

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Ha slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: It is not the aim of gentry to bring forth,
Such harsh unrelished fruit unto their wives,
And to their pretty pretty children by my troth.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: How rascal.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sir I must tell you, your progenitors
Two of the which these years were servant to,
Had not such mists before their understanding,
Thus to behave themselves.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: And you will control me sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Aye, I, will.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: You rogue.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I it is, I will tell you it is ungently done
Thus to defame your wife, abuse your children,
Wrong them, you wrong yourself, are they not yours?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Pretty, pretty Impudence i'faith,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Her whom your are bound to love, to rail against,
These whom you are bound to keep, to spurn like dogs,
If you were not my master, I would tell you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: What slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Put up your Bird-spit, tut I fear it not,
In doing deeds so base, so vild as these,
It is but a Kna, kna, kna.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Rogue.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Tut howsoever, it is a dishonest part,
And in defence of these I throw off duty

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Good Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Peace honest Mistress, I will say you are wronged,
Prove it upon him, even in his blood, his bones,
His guts, his Maw, his Throat, his Entrails.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: You runagate of threescore,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: It is better than a knave of three and twenty,

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Patience be my Buckler,
As not to file my hands in villains blood,
You knave Slave-trencher-groom
Who is your master?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: You if you were a master.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Off with your coat then, get you fort a doors.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: My cote sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Aye your coat slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: 'sfoot when you hate, it is but a thread-bare coat,
And there it is for you: know that I scorn
To wear his Livery is so worthy born,
And live so base a life, old as I am,
I will rather be a beggar than your man,
And there is your service for you.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Away, out of my door: Away.
So, now your Champions gone, Minx thou hadst better have gone
quick unto thy grave.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O me, that am no cause of it.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Then have suborned that slave to lift his hands against me.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: O me, what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: I will teach you tricks for this, have you a companion.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My heart not suffer me to leave my honest Mistress and her pretty children.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I will mark thee for a strumpet, and thy Bastards.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What will you do to them Sir.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.p: The Devil in thy shape come back again.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: No, but an honest servant Sir will take this cote,
And wear it with this sword to safeguard these,
And pity them, and I am woe for you,
But will not suffer
The husband Viper-like to pray on them.
That love her, and have cherished him as these,
As they have you.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will not humour you,
Fight with you, and lose my life or these
Shall taste your wrong whom you are bound to love.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Out of my doors slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will not, but will stay and wear this coat,
And do you service whether you will or no.
I will wear this sword too, and be Champion,
To fight for her in spite of any man.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: You shall. You shall be my master Sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: No, I desire it not,
I will pay you duty even upon my knee,
But lose my life, ere these oppressed I will see.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Yes goodman slave, you shall be master,
Lie with my wife, and get more Bastards, do, do, do.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: O me.

sp.speaker: scar
sp.l: Turns the world upside down, that men overbear their
Masters, It does, it does.
For even as Iudas sold his Master Christ,
Men buy and sell their wives at highest price,
What will you give me? what will you give me? what will you give me?
O, Mistress,
My soul weeps, though mine eyes be dry,
To see his fall and your adversity,
Some means I have left, which I will relieve you with,
Into your chamber, and if comfort be a kin
To such great grief, comfort your children.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: I thank thee Butler, heaven when he please,
Send death unto the troubled a blessed ease.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Introth I know not if it be good or ill,
That with this endless toil I labour thus,
It is but the old times Ancient conscience
That would do no man hurt, that makes me do it,
If it be sin that I do pity these,
If it be sin I have relieved his Brothers,
Have played the thief with them to get their food,
And made a luckless marriage for his Sister,
Intended for her good, heaven pardon me.
But if so, I am sure they are greater sinners,
That made this match, and were unhappy men,
For they caused all, and may heaven pardon them.

sp.speaker: sir Wil.
sp.l: Who is within here.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sir William, kindly welcome.

sp.speaker: sir Wil.
sp.l: Where is my kinsman Scarborrow?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sooth he is within sir, but not very well.

sp.speaker: sir Will.
sp.l: His sickness?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: The hell of sickness, troubled in his mind.

sp.speaker: sir Wil.
sp.l: I guess the cause of it,
But cannot now intend to visit him,
Great business for my sovereign hastes me hence,
Only this Letter from his Lord and Guardian to him,
Whose inside I do guess, tends to his good,
At my return I will see him, so farewell.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Whose inside I do guess turns to his good,
He shall not see it now then, for men's minds
Perplexed like his, are like Land-troubling-winds,
who have no gracious temper.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: O Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: What is the fright now?

sp.speaker: Irhn
sp.l: Help strait, or on the tree of shame
We both shall perish for the robbery.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: What is it revealed man?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Not yet good Butler, only my brother Thomas
In spleen to me, that would not suffer him
To kill our elder brother, had undone us
Is riding now to sir Iohn Harcop straight, to disclose it.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Heart, who would rob with Sucklings:
Where did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Now taking horse to ride to Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will stay his journey, lest I meet a hanging.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I will parley with the Devil: Aye, I will,
He gives his counsel freely, and the cause
He for his Clients pleads, goes always with them,
He in my cause shall deal then: and I will ask him
Whether a Cormorant may have stuffed Chests
And see his brother starve: why he will say Aye,
The less they give, the more I gain thereby.
Their souls, their souls, their souls.
How now master? Nay, you are my master?
Is my wives sheets warm? Does she kiss well?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Foe, make it not strange for in these days,
There is many men lie in their master's sheets,
And so may you in mine and yet: Your business sir?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: There is one in civil habit sir, would speak with you.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: In civil habit.

sp.speaker: But:
sp.l: He is of seemly rank sir, and calls himself
By the name of Doctor Baxtor of Oxford.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: That man undid me, he did blossoms blow
Whose fruit proved poison, tho it was good in show,
With him I will parley, and disrobe my thoughts
Of this wild frenzy that becomes me not:
A table, candles, stools, and all things fit,
I know he comes to chide me, and I will hear him,
With our sad conference we will call up tears,
Teach Doctors rules, instruct succeeding years:
Usher him in:
Heaven spare a drop from thence wheres bounties throng
Give patience to my soul, inflame my tongue.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: God master Scarborow.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: You are most kindly welcome, sooth ye are.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I have important business to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: And I have leisure to attend your hearing.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sir, you know I married you.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: I know you did sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: At which you promised both to God and men,
Your life unto your spouse should like snow,
That falls to comfort, not to overthrow,
And love unto your issue should be like
The dew of heaven, that hurts not though it strike,
When heaven and men did witness and record
It was an eternal oath, no idle word
Heaven being pleased therewith, blessed you with children,
And at heavens blessings, all good men rejoice.
So that Gods chair and footstool, heaven and earth
Made offering at your nuptials as a knot
To mind you of your vow, O break it not?

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: It is very true.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Now sir, from this your oath and band,
Faiths pledge, and seal of conscience you have run,
Broken all contracts, and the forfeiture,
Justice hath now in suit against your soul,
Angels are made the Iurots, who are witnesses
Unto the oath you took, and God himself
Maker of marriage, he that sealed the deed,
As a firm lease unto you during life,
Sirs now as judge of your transgression,
The world informs against you with this voice,
If such sins reign, what mortals can rejoice.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: What then ensues to me?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: A heavy doom, whose executions
Now served upon your conscience, that ever
You shall feele plagues whom time shall not dissever,
As in a map your eyes see all your life,
Bad words, worse deeds, false oaths, and all the injuries,
You have done unto your soul, then comes your wife,
Full of woes drops, and yet as full of pity,
who though she speaks not, yet her eyes are swords,
That cut your heartstrings, and then your children.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: who what they cannot say talk in their looks,
You have made us up, but as misfortunes books,
Whom other men may read in, when presently,
Tasked by yourself, you are not like a Thief,
Astonished being accused, but scorch with grief,

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, Aye.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Here stands your wives tears.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: And you fry for them, here lie your children's wants.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Here?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: For which you pine in conscience burn,
And wish you had been better, or never born.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Does all this happen to a wretch like me.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Both this and worse, your soul eternally
Shall live in torment, though the body die.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I shall have need of drink then Butler,

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Nay all your sins are on your children laid,
For the offences that the father made.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Are they Sir.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Be sure they are.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Go fetch my wife and children hither.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: sca.
sp.p: I will read a Letter to the Doctor. too, he is a Divine? Aye he is a Divine.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I see his mind is troubled, and have made bold with duty to read a Letter tending to his good, have made his Brothers friends: both which I will conceal till better temper: He sends me for his wife and children, shall I fetch them.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.p:
He is a Divine, and this Divine did marry me, that is
good, that is good,

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Master Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I will be with you straight Sir,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will obey him,
If anything doth happen that is Ill,
Heaven bear me record it is against Butlers will.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: And this Divine did marry me,
Whose tongue should be the key to open truth,
As Gods Ambassador. Deliver, deliver, deliver.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Master Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: sca.
sp.l: I will be with you straight sir,
Salvation to afflicted consciences,
And not give torment to contented minds,
who should be lamps to comfort out our way,
And not like Firedrakes to lead men astray,
Aye, I will be with you straight sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Here is your wife and children sir?

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Give way then,
I have my lesson perfect, leave us here

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Yes I will go, but I will be so near,
To hinder the mishap the which I fear.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Now sir, you know this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Kind mistress Scarborrow,

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Nay pray you keep your seat, for you shall hear,
The same affliction you have taught me fear,
Due to yourself.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: To me sir.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: To you sir,
You matched me to this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I know I did sir.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: And you will say she is my wife then.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: I have reason sir, because I married you.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: O that such tongues should have the time to lie,
who teach men how to live, and how to die,
Did not you know my soul had given my faith,
In contract to another, and yet you
Would join this Loom unto unlawful twists.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: But sir,
You that can see a Mote within my eye,
And with a Cassock blind your own defects,
I will teach you this, it is better to do ill,
That is never known to us, than of self will,
And these all these in thy seducing eye,
As scorning life make them be glad to die.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Me Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Here will I write, that they which marry wives,
Unlawful live with strumpets all their lives.
Here will I seal the children that are born,
From wombs unconsecrate, even when their soul
Has her infusion, it registers they are foul,
And shrinks to dwell with them, and in my close,
I will show the world, that such abortive men,
Knit hands without free tongues look red like them
Stand you and you, to acts most Tragical,
Heaven has dry eyes, when sin, makes sinners fall.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Help master Scarborrow,

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: These for thy act should die, she for my Clare,
Whose wounds stare thus upon me for revenge.
These to be rid from misery, this from sin,
And thou thyself shalt have a push amongst them,
That made heavens word a pack-horse to thy tongue.
Contest scripture to make evils shine like good,
And as I send you thus with worms to dwell,
Angels applaud it as a deed done well.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Stay him, stay him.
What will you do sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Make fat worms of stinking carcasses,
What hast thou to do with it?

div.stage: Enter Ilford and his wife, the two Brothers, and Sir William Scarborrow

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Look who are here sir.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Injurious villain that preventest me still.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: They are your brothers and alliance Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: They are like full ordinance then, who once discharged,
A far off give a warning to my soul,
That I had done them wrong.

sp.speaker: sir Wil
sp.l: Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Brother and sister.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: scar,
sp.l: Hark how their words like Bullets shoot me through
And tell me I have undone them, this side might say.
We are in want, and you are the cause of it,
This points at me, you are shame unto your house,
This tongue says nothing, but her looks do tell,
She is married but as those that live in hell:
Whereby all eyes are but misfortunes pipe,
Filled full of woe by me, this feels the stripe.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Yet look Sir,
Here is your Brothers hand in hand, whom I have knit so.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And look Sir here is my husbands hand in mine,
And I rejoice in him, and he in me.

sp.speaker: sir wil.
sp.l: I say Cos what is past, the way to bliss,
For they know best to mend, that know amiss,

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: We kneel, forget, and say if you but love us,
You gave us grief for future happiness.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: What all this to my Conscience?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Ease, promise of succeeding joy to you,
Read but this Letter.

sp.speaker: sir Will.
sp.l: Which tells you that your Lord and Guardians dead.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Which tells you that he knew he did you wrong,
Was grieved for it, and for satisfaction
Hath given you double of the wealth you had.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Increased our portions.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Given me a dowry too.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: And that he knew,
Your sin was his, the punishment his due.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: All this is here,
Is heaven so gracious to sinners then?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Heaven is, and has his gracious eyes,
To give men life not like entrapping spies.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Your hand, yours, yours, to you my soul, to you a kiss,
Introth I am sorry I have strayed amiss,
To whom shall I be thankful. All silent:
None speak: whist: why then to God,
That gives men comfort as he gives his rod,
Your portions I will see paid, and I will love you,
You three I will live withal, my soul shall love you,
You are an honest servant, sooth you are,
To whom, I these and all must pay amends,
But you I will admonish in cool terms,
Let not promotions hope, be as a string,
To tie your tongue, or let loose it to sting.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: From hence it shall not Sir.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Then husbands thus shall nourish with their wives.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: As thou and I will wench.
Brothers in brotherly love thus link together,

sp.speaker: sca.
sp.l: Children and servants pay their duty thus.
And all are pleased.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are.

sp.speaker: scar.
sp.l: Then if all these be so,
I am new wed so ends old marriage woe,
And in your eyes so lovingly being wed,
We hope your hands will bring us to our bed.
